content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								Project Zomboid is a refreshing gem in the survival game genre.When I bought this game in 2011, long before steam greenlight, I stumbled upon this game on YouTube.It was far from what you have seen before, the closest thing to it at the time was minecraft.The developers humble about their little project.Back then the map was tiny, weapons did not exist in the quantity they do now, the food system we have now did not exist, multiplayer was a massive requested feature but was thought to never happen, there was no progression system the graphics were odd, you get the idea it was not a big game.Now, after 5 years a lot has changed, it has become quite a survival game.Since the steam review section consists mainly out of overused memes, people complaining about their PC not being able to handle the games and people ranting with 1000 hours that the game sucks I will post more of an introduction than a review. I will of course say what is good and what is missing but I will focus on it more in detail than a short review would.At the bottom I will sum everything up with a TL;DRWhat makes the game good?Its combat system:Overall the combat system is satisfying.You don't feel too strong or too weak. Your character feels like he is hitting bodies made out of bone and flesh, not bodies made out of papierm√¢ch√© or not rocks like in other games.There are three different types of combat:BluntBladeRagedBlunt consists out of bats, spiked bats and sledgehammersBlade consists out of Knives and AxesRanged consists out of Pistols, Shotguns and RiflesIf enemies get too close (hugging close) an axe won't do much damage a knife however will. A blunt weapon is efficient as long as the enemy is in reach however, it won't do as much damage as a close ranged knife or an axe.Guns do good amount of damage if the enemy is at the right distance. If the enemy gets in melee range it won't be nearly as accurate as if he is a few meters away.Axes have a sweet spot where the blade contacts with the enemy where they will be the most efficient. If you swing too much your character won't hit as hard.Mood and Needs:Your character of course does not stroll through the zombie apocalypse like it's nothing, under all those pixels he also had emotions and needs which this game wants to deliver to you. Your character can feel a variety of things which affect his combat and health.Your character can feel pain, sadness, nausea, panic, sadness, boredom, hunger and thirst, exhaustion, tiredness and temperature.All these affect you somehow, pain and panic for example can reduce your accuracy with weapons, if you are in great pain you won't be able to sleep.Hunger and thirst obviously will kill you if they get to great.Boredom and Sadness don't do‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•but change the appearance of the world (it becomes darker), in the future however they will play a bigger role.Nausea makes you recover less if injured or if you get really sick by eating that month old lasagne then you may die.Exhaustion makes you a slow weakling.Tiredness reduces your awareness and ultimately makes you collapse on the street if it gets too bad.Your character can defeat zombies, that means he is also able to overcome his emotions. here are some examples.If you are in great pain you can take pain killers.If you are bored you can go outside, mom will be proud or get drunk dad will be proud . He can also read or something.If you are tired you can drink a coffee, you can also use the ancient chinese trading secret method of sleeping.If you are thirsty you can drink out of the toilet bowel, and so on.Your character also adapts over time, he is less prone to panic the longer he is around zombies and is not so emotionally impacted after seeing corpses all day.What about progression and stats?Project Zomboid lets your character develope over his lifetime and you get to already influence your character's skills and talents while you are creating him.While creating your character, you can chose his pre-apocalypse profession and his traits, the higher the benefits of these professions the less points you can spend on other traits.There are many traits and professions so I will only give one example.You want your character to be able to build objects that can actually stand? Then you can pick carpender, this gives your character more experience in carpentry allowing him to build more complex objects right off the bat.If your character does something often, he will gain more experience and gain level, this can improve how efficient your character with the knife on the field, or in the kitchen and much more.How much can you control in the environment? Your character can farm, build, and scavenge.If you don't want to starve then you need to plant food, if you don't want to get killed by a horde then you need to be able to build sturdy houses and if you want tools you need to scavenge for rocks to build tools.There are many differnt crops that you get to plant, you need to plow the soil, water them regularly and make sure no one steps on them.For building there are many different structures to chose from, the things you build become more sturdy the more expereience you have. This can been seen not just by their hitpoints but also visually.Challenge:Project Zomboid is a game that is challenging for new players but once you get the hang of it, it gets pretty easy. After a month of playing the electricity and water supply will turn off because the power plant will get over run. This forces the player to find a well in the middle of nowhere to obtain more water or to drink out of every toilet bowel in the city. Since there is no power you can not refrigerate anymore, meaning you will have plant food yourself. There is no greater goal to accomplish but not dying which truly makes this game a survival game, this can get boring over time.There are things to still be added:A much requested feature are NPC, they once were in the game (around 2012) however the developers found that they simply were not smart enough, so they removed them. Since then they have been working on them and other projects so they won't blow‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•once they are in the game, people simply have to be patient.Other things like generators a nutricion system is coming too, so don't you dare think that the developers have become lazy. The fact that these guys are still dedicated to this game after such a long time (this being their first project) is very comforting to know. They are also remaking the visuals and combat system for the third time to make it even better, you can check their YouTube channel for some footage of that. They always have new ideas and mods can also improve on the experience. (Here is my favorit one as an example)There are things I can not mention because of the character limit on steam, like the map editor for example.TL;DR:Project Zomboid is a game with a great atmosphere. With a satisfying combat system, needs and moods, alongside a trait and experience system and a great soundtrack, it succeeds at delivering an entertaining experience.The game still has not reached full replay value since you are all alone but if you buy a copy with a friend it will definitely last you a lot of hours, don't let that shy you away however since even alone this game will deliver.Since patches come regularly with the developers listening and interacting with the community on their forum I can only recommend this as an early access.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Day 1 My first in-game day was spent wandering around and trying to figure out the controls. I picked up some food and a baseball bat and ran around smashing windows, climbing inside people's houses and looting. After caving in a few Z-heads I was told I was thirsty. I drank some water from a toilet and all was well. I was then told I was hungry. Searching in a house I found a "TV Dinner", which sounded perfect. I walked over and put it in the oven. While I was waiting for it to cook I read a book. A short time later I came over to the oven only to find I had burnt my TV dinner. The game told me I would get depressed and unhappy should I eat it. I did. I was instantly overwhelmed with depression and told I was tired. I went to sleep on the couch. Day 2 The next morning I awoke in an unhappy mood. I was playing about with the controls and somehow managed to accelerate time at an alarming rate. After smashing some keys I finally got it back to normal. My character was hungry, thirsty, bored, depressed and tired now. O goodie. I found a steak and slung it in the oven to cook. I was not going to let this meal burn, so I stood there watching it cook. The instant it was finished I grabbed it and scoffed the whole thing. As is tradition, I washed it down with some toilet water. I was told my character was going to collapse (presumably because he had been awake for about 2 days solid due to the time accelerating-issue). I curled up on the sofa and went to sleep. Day 4? I woke up in the middle of the night and could not see a thing. I thought it best I continue with my book in the pitch black, so began reading for a bit. Morning came and I was hungry and thirsty. I searched around the neighbourhood for supplies and came across a packet of cigarettes and some peanut butter. I ate the cigarettes and the peanut butter and sipped some more toilet water. I also found a backpack and various other supplies. I went on a journey north. My mood seemed to change as I smashed Z after Z' head in. My depression lifted and I found new vigour. As the day went on I looted a liquor shop for crisps and ice-cream and broke into a farm house to steal a hammer and nails. ....that's pretty much how my game went so far.Jimbo Rating: 7/10

content:
Posted: February 26
Early Access Review
								I wish I could recommend this game as it was and still is a good concept and the execution isn't done that bad at all. Combat is a little clunky at times but the survival aspects are well done in my opinion and are fairly in-depth. With a slew of status effects derived from environemtal conditions to emotional factors such as anxiety, fear and depression, just to name a few, there is quite a varried platter of outcomes for each players death and it makes for a pretty neat replayability factor since the survival is intended to be very difficult. However through all the many years I've had this title development has been slugish at best and now it seems as though the developers have lost motivation to get a finished product to the many backers that enjoyed their concept. Seriously around 7 years in early access and this is all you have to offer? I could accept the lack of progess if there were low amounts of sales but honestly this game has sold quite decently, at least well enough to warrant hiring a few ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• employees to get your product FINISHED. These guys are so unprofessional they are just now starting to deliver on features they promised all the way back in 2015! If that doesn't scream incompitence I don't know what does. Save your money and don't invest in this concept, because that's all it is at this point. There is not enough gameplay elements to keep you interested for very long and even with multiplayer the lack of activities to carry out make for a bland experience. I hope to see this game make some sort of progress towards a final release. Maybe I'll check back in another 7 years to see if it's done yet :)

content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								When I decided to look at the store page for this game, I was genuinely surprised to see a seemingly unending cascade of negative reviews. On one hand, I can see things from their perspective, and I can see why these people ultimately do not recommend this game. However, I'd like to address claims made by these people, validating some and disproving others. This review is aimed at people on the fence about purchasing this game.In its current state, this game is great fun. I've had experiences on this game that one could not get anywhere else. Granted, these experiences were only possible due to the multiplayer experience. Experiences such as building whole communities that were genuinely life-like, and on the other hand, watching them inevitably collapse. This game has far more depth than most games of this genre. It is not without its problems, but I will touch on those later.A lot of people are claiming this game has not changed in the last 4-5 years. This is the most myopic claim I see people make, so I'd like to address this one first. This game has indeed changed a lot. Some of these changes seem quite small, but have had large impact on the game. Some examples of how this game has changed are as follows:Revamped medical/health system.Revamped skills, traits, and character progression.Addition of skills such as foraging, trapping, fishing, metalworking, etc.Addition of skills such as aiming, accuracy, etc. All of which increase as your character survives.Addition of a nutrition system.Addition of player-made traps such as nail traps, bombs, etc. (Significant impact in multiplayer.)Added professions such as engineer, electrician, metalworker, etc. (In tandem with added skills.)Greatly improved horde migration and zombie spawning.Revamped UI and inventory system.Multiplayer optimization and voice support. (Significant impact in multiplayer.)Improved cooking system. (Ability to bake bread and learn recipes.)World building through radio and TV broadcasts. (Players are able to broadcast through radio in multiplayer.)UX improvements pulled from the forum suggestions thread. (Such as highlighted containers when looting them.)Added world decay and seasons. (Vines creep up the walls of housing, road decay, nature slowly taking over, etc.)Modding support.Greatly improved sound engine and ambienceSandbox options that allow the player to customize their apocalypse experience.All of these changes have made the game feel more complete and wholesome. The singleplayer audience would understandably leave this game to age in their library. Without the diversity of human interaction, as frustrating as it may be at times, I do not think this game would live. The experiences you can have that will make this game worth far more than its asking price are simply not possible without multiplayer, and to be honest, not even with the inclusion of promised NPCs. The NPCs many are asking for would be considered wonderfully ahead of their time, provided they make release. To call the devs lazy is another narrowminded insult, as the devs share their progress with the community on a weekly basis. I see many call these mondoids "useless," and then these same people will accuse the devs of being too lazy to work on the game, even though what the devs are working on and what their progress is has just been disclosed.However, these negative reviews are not all entirely wrong. Development progress is rather slow. However, you have to understand that this game started off as a one-man project. It is impressive for how far it has come, though it has a way to go before meeting its rather large ambitions.It is important to keep in mind that the updates The Indie Stone releases are very polished and go through weeks of playtesting to ensure highest quality once it hits the main branch. Even bugfixes go through this playtesting stage to ensure fixes do not create more problems. It is evident the devs do genuinely care about their game because of the amount of polish each update goes through.The heavy amount of negative reviews is worrying because not only are they rather hasty in their analysis, but in addition, they lead the would-be player to assume the game is in a failing, bug-ridden, and unenjoyable state.In its current state, the game is far from unenjoyable. If you pick this game up, especially if on sale, and hop onto a server, whether it be your own or a larger public one, you will find that this game meets expectations for its asking price of a mere $15.I've been a radio host, a member of a rebellion in a community, been surrounded in a building by a de-facto police force, been a lone wolf, a bartender, a member of a cannibalistic faction, a double-agent, taken part in defending a player-made town from a horde, been kidnapped and forced to fight to the death with planks and frying pans, been robbed, robbed others, hid in a closet while a serial killer murdered men just outside my door, overheard conversations not meant for my ears, been spied on, found bases hidden in the woods, ran trade routes, etc.I do recommend purchasing this game. At the very least, keep your eye on this one for when it releases animations and other updates.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'm a huge fan of true survival games, like don't starve. where it's hard to survive and, if possible at all, even harder to thrive. During the winter sale I was looking for a new survival game to play, and this always proves to be a difficult task because there are so many fake survival games, games that with enough grinding you can easily thrive.So I decided to give project zomboid a try, and the game positively surprised me.It is a really hard game where if you be careful enough, you'll be able to survive, but a minor screw up can and will kill you. Wasn't prepared for that zombie in the bathroom of a house you thought was empty? He can scratch you or bite you, giving you a high chance of zombification, an illness with no cure in the game. Yes, you a zombie manages to scratch or bite you, there's a big chance that the game over timer will start ticking.And even if you isolate yourself from the huge amounts of zombie in the forested areas of the huge (HUGE) map, you'll still will have to deal with food and water. Food can be preserved for more time in fridges, but guess what? After a random amount of days, the power will be cut out. You can drink water from sinks and toilets, but just like the power, water will also be cut out after a random amount of days.The character creation is fantastic as well, and the trait system reminds me of old fallout games. You have good and bad traits that give you negative and positive points, respectively. You can only start the game if you have 0 or more points so you'll need to balance your character accordingly.And it has multiplayer! I had loads of fun playing with two people, scavenging the city for supplies, reinforcing a place to call home...And finally, another thing that really surprised me was the amount of zombies in the game. Depending on your luck and area in the game, you can stumble upon hordes and hordes of zombies. This feels just like the walking dead, and in fact it's one of the games that feels most like the series, apart from the telltale's ones, of course.This game is still in early access and it's loads of fun. I can't even think of how it will look and play when it's done.

number of helpful: 18 of 26 people (69%) found this review helpful9 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								I quickly discovered something important about Project Zomboid - I'm not very good.  Spinning to face a zombie, I recalled my son's reaction when I beat a guy one-on-one in a shootout in WolfET.  He looked at my dead opponent and said "thank you for sucking".I bring this up because I can set Sandbox Mode to ease me into harder and harder levels.  Nobody's gona watch me on YouTube if I'd been recording my playthroughs (I haven't been)(you're welcome), but poor little Joey Fatone has a pretty good base set up, and his much tougher brother Fred Fatone is working on his own.  I'm learning the system, and having a ball.Most guys will play PZ like it's Dwarf Fortress ("Losing is Fun!") which is great, but it's your call.  There's a deep and satisfying skill system, but that's poorly suited to die-in-a-week scenarios.  So you make an important choice when you start the game, entirely apart from which Fatone brother to play and what skills he has.  Sandbox can be adjusted to encourage learning a lot, Survival, well, not so much unless you're adept.  I've seen enough playthroughs to convince me that very, very few guys, and I don't mean old ones like me, will bother much with most skills if they know that living a month is unlikely.   The game has not yet reached a point, however, where an effective base will be fun for very long, at least not your second or third one.  If you make yourself safe and reasonably self-sustaining, you've won, and it's probably time for a new Fatone.But, the game lets you pick what style you want.  Anyone remotely interested in the genre, basically anyone interested enough to be reading this, should enjoy the game.  Just don't expect to live forever, you're Joey Fatone, not Justin Timberlake.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								I played a lot of zombieslasher/ survival games ( Left 4 dead, Resident Evil, 7 days to die, dying light, ...) so Project Zomboid seemed to be a good choice. It is supposed to fill the gap between crafting games and survival games but (in my opinion) fails in some important aspects.After a fun character creation (profession, many ridicolous attributes to choose from: deaf, obese ...) and a difficulty choice you spawn in your apartment in an undead infested world. You explore a giant world with towns and forrests all the while defending yourself against zombies and the elements of nature. There is no hope of survival! (and thats the problem)This is one of those games you think should be great but once you actually try it out, its just lackluster and a waste of time. Here is why: Fighting System You kill endless hordes of undead which all behave the same (some slower or faster but thats it) and look pretty similar after some time. This might be "classic zombie behaviour" but has to be counteracted by engaging and fun combat mechanics. Its simply not fun to right click, then hold the attack until the zombie is in reach and release the mouse button. The zombie either stumbles and falls over or you have to walk backwards and repeat. Once its down simply stomp it to death.This is fun  for like a hundred zombies and becomes a chore afterwards.I dont mind killing zombie hordes after hordes in any other zombie game but somehow this game sucked the fun out of it. Even worse that the whole map is crawling with zombies and you have to waste many real life hours to clear an area. But then you wont meet a damn zombie there for a loong time since they only respawn when you leave area for a longer period of time.Not even the guns can salvage the complete lack of zombie-slaying fun since they are hard to come by (good) but utterly useless since they alarm every zombie around. They are also clunky and require a high shooting skill to hit anything even in close proximity. You also have no real way of aiming with a crosshair, only general pointing and praying for a hit. Variation There are multiple weapons in this game: Pencils, knifes, axes, baseball bats, shotguns, pistol and lots more.BUT they mostly look literally the same (a lot of melee weapons look like the baseball bat) and handle pretty similar in combat. Crafting seems exciting since you have they choice between hundreds of recipes (even generators which can power lamps or a fridge). But the amount of stuff you have to find until you can craft these things is huge and can take a long time of wandering around the map searching for random loot. The result is simply not worth the grind. The UI makes handling you inventory quite annoying and needs a serious overhaul.Long term goal/ motivationThe main reason i cant recommend this is the complete lack of motivation to actually survive. You gonna die anyway so why even hoard supplies or farm endlessly? L4d has saferooms and some kind of escape in the unknown. 7 days to die has huge building projects to undertake (also kind of pointless but still). Resident Evil, Dying Light and many other zombie games use a story line to keep the player engaged.Project Zomboid has nothing but building youself a poor mans fort and play farmer till you get bored to death. Of course you can still have a lot of fun but simply imagining a story in your head but why take this from the devs shoulders? There is mainly one thing which would boost the stale gameplay: NPCs combined with some long term goal ( cure, Escape or whatever). This brings us to: Development PaceThis game is in development for about 5 years and gets updates every few weeks but doesnt progress anymore. The recently addet TVs and radios dont even have sound! They just repeat the same written lines like in retro games (sounds in fallout 2 for example).The developer essays are interesting to read at first but get annoying very soon. If there happens a major update which actually implements some kind of content apart from wandering the map, killing samey zombies and looting endless containers i will gladly update my review.Until then i cannot recommend this game at all.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								Hands down the best zombie survival game i have ever seen.The map is still under progress, but it's already huge with two major towns , and many factories / hidden places.The zombies are really well coded, and everything is taken into account : the noise you make, if you are visible through a window, if they see light inside a building, ect...Also, your character can only see what's in front of him, you thought you'd have a nice, aerial view of every danger around ? Nope.The variety of items that can be found is huge, it makes the game very realistic, and scavenging all the more interesting.The weapon system is made in a way that you can't kill many zombies easily, so it's vital to establish strategies like catching the attention of zombies to get them away from your shelter, and loose them by running between trees.The graphics are great, the game is light and will run on most computers.This game is everything DayZ (and many other similar games) should have been, and it keeps getting better with every update, thanks to the awesome Devs.Did i forget to mention it ? This game is very hard. You're going to die. Quickly.

number of helpful: 12 of 15 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2013
Early Access Review
								The only thing I can say is stupid or lame about this game is that it has "Project" in the official title. However, this game is a masterpiece in the open world survival genre, pitting you against mankind's greatest foe. Care to take a guess? The answer is not zombies. It's your own bodily functions. The easy to avoid zombies start to look a little more dangerous with each bit of your health slowly disappearing over time, whether you're spiraling into insanity, or catching the common cold, or growing bored and wet. And you thought hunger and thirst were bad enough.To further add onto the awesome, Zomboid has a functioning split-screen mode as well as a working online mutliplayer that came as quite a shock to a number of players who never expected it to see the light of day. Among that, it features a micromanageable difficulty in which you can alter anything from playing with a mass of zombies or completely alone (which is oddly terrifying), to altering how much loot you have, what kind of weather you'll see, infection conditions, and even modify zombie AI. And then you get a lot of mod functionality from allowing gameplay changes to custom professions. Even at Early Access, Project Zomboid is already working on a solid (and a little buggy) foundation, and is definitely worth checking out.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								TL:DR for people who just want the quick and silly reviewsI convinced my friend to eat a roasted cockroach and then watched him succumb to disease. 10/10, would make my friends eat roaches again.Now, with that out of the way, Project Zomboid is a zombie survival game which has been in steady development for the last six or so years. It takes place in the town of Muldraugh Kentucky and the surrounding areas of Knox County. (Fun fact, the scene in which the villians  men are marching up a street with a tank towards Fort Knox in the James Bond film "Gold Finger" was shot in Muldraugh.) Over the course of it's development, Project Zomboid has suffered some outstanding set backs. Paypal and Google freezing Indie Stones accounts, Piracy of the game early in it's development, and the theft of a large amount of code stored on a pair of laptops. Despite all that, Project Zomboid is still here, and it has come a hell of a long way. Gameplay involves scavanging supplies from the houses belonging to your ex neighbors, fortifying a house to hold off the steadily increasing number of zombies, and generally trying to set up some kind of long term survival. Zombies have infectious bites/scratches, which is an issue I have with the game. When you get bit or scratched, you might as well just quit. No point in continuing to play a doomed character. Fortunately, the sandbox mode allows you to turn the infection off, or tweak the gameplay and zombies in many other ways. The game also features basic crafting and construction, which allow you to make a few small utility items, or build very simple structures. Cooking is a good source of fun, especially when you are playing with friends. The best part is making rat soup and making your friends eat it. The game also features a fair bit of random variable when it comes to the zombies. Noises of any kind usually attract them, including the ambient noises you hear around you as you explore. A major source of game ending noise are burgler alarms and helicopters. The burgler alarm triggers sometimes when you break into a house, the noise it makes can be heard for miles and will attract every single zombie within that area of effect. They will descend upon the house and rip it apart searching for the source of the noise, not to mention you if you are fool enough to hang around said house. The other source, helicopters, have a large range of noise and if they come by while you are outside, they will follow you around. Imagine a news helicopter trying to get footage of an unfortunate survivor, unaware that their presence is dooming him/her. Other noises such as gunshots, barking dogs, screaming people, serve the same purposes but to a lesser extent. The ambiant noises occur once, and basically just move zombies in a shortish range towards the sounds origin point. It also serves as a bit of atmosphere. Speaking of screaming people, NPC are planned. You can go to the community hub and see as everyone demands and complains ceaselessly about the lack of NPC's. Some of them even know that zomboid DID have NPC's once. They were horrifyingly buggy and were removed to be worked on at a later date. For now, the game is perfectly playable as is, if a little empty. If you want to fill that world out a bit, make it seems a bit less empty...You can play Zomboid with your friends. The new easy co-op is out as of 5/9/2016 and I am deeply thankful that it is. Hosting multiplayer with friends has gone was a horrifying hassle of opening and forewarding ports, running external server programs, and friends issues with relayed tunneling. It is now a simple, streamlined, click-and-go system. Thanks Indie stone, and thanks to General Arcade for helping them get it worked out. The new co-op multiplayer is great. You can even allocate how much ram you want for the server from inside the game. It is really easy to use, and thanks to it, I can force my friends to eat rat based meals and roasted cockroaches.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								Today I got utterly ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•-faced on Chardonnay, fell off a roof, got trapped in a toilet by several zombies after my baseball bat broke because I was too drunk to kill them, got thirsty and had to drink toilet water and then fought my way out by stabbing them to death with a spoon. When I got home I discovered my broccoli patch had rotted. Just another day in Zomboid land.To qualify this a little; I have no real interest in zombies (either in games, film or tv) and don't much care for survival games, even less so early access. Took a punt on this after Steam threw it up randomly in my recommended list (I think because I play Alien: Isolation) and I read a few reviews. PZ manages that rare thing of being a pretty hardcore, serious game which should be quite depressing in many ways but somehow manages to also provide deeply satisfying moments of hilarity and 'how the hell did I get out of that?' gameplay. It throws you in at the deepend and resolutely refuses to offer you a hand, let alone a life vest. You will die, often and when you least expect it. You will only have yourself to blame, or the git who put a burglar alarm on their house. I'd recommend reading as little as possible by way of guides and wikis and just going at it, the sense of bewilderment and confusion and the resultant satisfaction from figuring stuff out is part of the fun. Lastly, the devs seem very active in the community and there are great looking updates on the horizon. This game is shaping up to be a bit of a cult classic.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've owned this game for quite some time and am only now really getting in to it.  When I first played this game I was getting killed just about every day and thought 'meh'.  I started again recently and instead of playing 'gung ho' style(sing it with me) I have been taking my time, reading tutorials, tips and crafting guides when I get stuck.I've tried Survival and Sandbox and much prefer the sandbox version of the game(I don't die as quickly).  The thing I love about this game?  If I die my body becomes a zombie, I then can create a new character and can go and kill that zombie and get all my stuff back.  Any structure I created is there for that new character, hell even down to  keeping a journal, die, pick up the old journal and continue the journal as a new character has some weird satisfaction. This game is not for the 'half an hour at a time player', not to say you cant play that way, but it's best played if you have about 3 hours or more to spend at a time.  The map is large, I didn't realize just how large this map was till running from point A to B trying to find the user created maps I added.Graphics are not what this games about but they do the job.Customization before a sandbox game begins gives you just about everything you could think of to tweak it to your own liking.I have left 7DTD to play this game, and I absolutely believed that it couldn't get better than 7DTD, time will tell!

It doe not seem to have yet, though don't get me wrong since I feel as if I at one point got my value out of playing it. If you really want to pick up this title, I would wait until it is out of devepoment because of how radically things can change from update to update.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is how you died.The entirety of the game is how you died. There is a mystery as to why the zombie outbreak occurred, and you might even find some answers before you die. Ultimately though, Project Zomboid does not represent an against-all-odds struggle where you overcome the undead. Instead, after dying, every subsequent playthrough just lets you survive a little longer, do a little better, and  learn a little more.Death can come in many, many ways. You have to manage needs, similar to The Sims . You need to eat, sleep, and even need to rest your legs if you're running around too much . You aren't able to see meters that indicate your exact state, but moodlets will appear to let you know exactly what your character is thinking or feeling at any given time. Injuries are common, so if you're scratched or bitten by a zombie, you better tend to them quickly.The town is populated by other survivors and looters, some just as desperate as you. Everyone is  scared by the thousands of zombies roaming the city, and a looter just might find you and put a shotgun round in your chest as he takes your food and other supplies. Scripted events like this will keep you on your toes, but with every failure comes the chance to prepare a little better for next time.The zombies themselves are the slow and lumbering kind. You can fairly easily outrun them, but they are legion, and don't easily forget. They are attracted by blood and noise, and all it takes is a single mistake to advertise your location to the horde. You've never had to think in so many different directions and cover your butt in so many different ways before. As a result, every moment is exciting because you never know what lurks around the corner and whether you missed that one thing that will give away your position. Getting into a routine and locking down your safehouse will be just as important as finding food and scavenging for weapons.Crafting is also a large part of Project Zomboid. At the moment, your character already "knows" the recipes needed to create objects to help him: combining a can opener, a can of soup, and a pot results in a big pot of edible soup, for example. Cooking will eventually be part of the game as well, adding another layer of complexity to basic survival; after all, you don't want to be suffering from food poisoning due to eating undercooked meat if you're being chased down by zombies.Overall, well worth a buy. It's easy to see that Project Zomboid has potential and lots of merits. Recommended

number of helpful: 11 of 14 people (79%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have been looking for a zombie survival game for years- a good one. Something I could play for awhile, something that wouldn't leave me feeling like there could be 'more'a. I remeber the first time I heard of H1Z1, and DayZ- they both sounded amazing. Looking at screenshots, how could I not be impressed?How naive. If you really look around for any zombie apocalypse games, those two names are bound to come up, and with them, their history of major, major disappointment. A couple days ago, I was looking through my Steam Queue, and Project Zomboid happened to pop up. Watching the video, I was intrigued. Yeah, the graphics weren't photorealistic, but then again, when did they ever have to be? When I looked towards the reviews and comments, I was estatic, and could only hope it measured up.It totally did.I've only played a few hours as of this review, but I'm absolutely hooked. In its current state, it is completely playable, and worth its $14.99 price tag. Pros- Realistic survival simulationDeath comes swift and quick for those who don't pay enough attention. From basic survival needs like food and water, the game goes beyond and even throws in challenges in other forms. Staying out in the rain might get you sick, and if you don't take care of that, you might be visiting the Grim Reaper pretty soon. You can be cold, scratched, bitten, and you can bleed, and feel nausea and so much more. Honestly, you get screwed over pretty quick- Good UINot much to say. It's got clean menus, and useful graphics. - Good PersonalizationDo you love zombie games? Do you still suck at killing them? No worries. This game has quite a few different play styles, each one taking place at a different time in the apocalypse. The Initial Infection (a non-canon play for those of us who suck at the games we love), The First Week (where things start to pick up, and those zombies really start to pay closer attention to you), Six Months Later (the name says it all, but you better know how to get water for yourself...), and the last mode, Survival, where you see how long it takes you to die. The first three modes even have more difficulty options within them, so you really get to pick what type of game you want to play.-  The fact that this is only Early AccessThis game feels full, alive (or, uh, undead?), and pretty complet minus some bugs here or there. The fact that this game will only get better is really exciting! Cons - Melee/ selection dificultiesBy no means rendering the game unplayable, but melee is always the way I go. This could just be my game, but I occasionally have issues with fighting zombies. I'll be aimed right on them, but whatever weapon I'm beating them with will move right through them. Moving around a bit usually helps this, but it can be an ocasional annoyance.-  Cooking is burdensome Not something that is super problematic, but still worth mentioning. Some players have found cooking to be a hit and miss problem without the help of the wikia or other guides. Recipes, unless you know them, can leave you confused on what you can and can't cook. Yeah, you can make soup. But, no, you can't make bowls of cereal and milk (which I know from my own tragic expirience). Conclusion or tl;dr The problems in Project Zomboid are very minimal, and are not enough to turn a player away from the game. What you get with this a really fun game that you can play for hours on end. Whether you want to build a fort, or leech off existing houses, live in a Zombie-filled city, or a blank country side, you're in charge of your own tragic and inevitable death.It's fifteen bucks of sign-me-the-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•-up. If you wanna see how you'd fair in the zombie apocalypse, here's your game Pluss the mascot is a raccoon. A cute raccoon. Who doesn't love trash pandas?

I started up the game and was greated by a mess of tabs and menus. After sorting it out I began to play the game with default features. I immediatley found the things I needed for the rest of my playthrough. 67 canned soup and beans, a plethora of weapons and ammo, all the medical supplies that I could find, a saw and hammer with 9 boxes of nails, and a large hiking bag I found on a corpse. I was all set. I found a storage warehouse and barricaded every window and a perimeter fence around the 20 block area of it. I made a large farm that provides me with more tomatoes and potatoes I can eat. I wound up forgetting about the zombies for day 22-34 and was shocked to see a shambler inside of a zippos pizzarea. I was almost longing for a  way to attract the snackers, walkers, biters, ect to my base.The over all experience was so-so. I have high hopes for this game in the future. hopefully I wont have to settle on burning houses with dead rats in the oven.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								At first glance this game looks relatively simplistic, a simple art style in a sandbox zombie game. But this game has incredible depth. Managing your various states whether you are hungry or thirsty, in a state of panic or anger, wet or overheated, encumbered, sleepy, sick and much much more.This game is tough, the procedural generation makes each play through unique and can be your best friend or your worst enemy. You might load into a house with an axe and a pistol or you could be heading out armed with a spoon or fork and this is what makes this game great.Each game feels like a real survivors story, you are not a hero, you are just trying to stay alive as long as you can before meeting your untimely demise.I am excited for future development of this game and the new features promised look to improve this great game even further. As for the bad, my only current complaint is the multiplayer system. Hosting a server is a nightmare to do and a server tool or using steam would greatly improve this issue aside from that I am enjoying the game and hope they create a better multiplayer option soon.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Found an abandoned house in the forest after marching through the rain for what seemed like hours. The warmth of the fire from the stone helped me calm my nerves as the moans of the undead could be heard not far from where I was. I checked the cabinets for food. No luck. I checked the fridge. Nothing. There had to be something in this place. If the dead didn't get to me, starvation would. Finally, after searching the entire house, I found a bag of chips underneath the couch in the living room. They were the best stale chips I've had in what felt like days. For the very first time, I felt like everything was going to be alright, until I noticed the curtains in the living room window were still open, and the undead had spotted me. Their moans attracted more of them as they began to surround the house, smashing through the windows. Me, with my trust crowbar ran into the bathroom, fearing that this was the end. I closed the door behind me and frankly searched for a way out. Panic settled in as the realization that I had no way out with the undead banging at the bathroom door sank in.I didn't survive 20 minutes after starting the game. 10 out of 10.For a game that's only in Early Access and has come this far makes me proud to play it. This is truly what an Early Access release should look like. It can only go up from here.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								From all the zombie survival games I have ever played, this one hits most aspects I hoped for the genre. The goal of the game is simple, you must get from being a survivor to a rebuilder of a one-man society. You are on a time limit as the utilities will soon shut down within weeks, so you must quickly locate your pernament base and fortify it, then start building a garden and several rain catcher barrels to produce food and water. Melee weapons are more important than firearms, and fire can cause a little more destruction than necessary. The zombies, of course, can see, hear, and smell you, so cover up the windows and stick to the shadows and downwind to avoid detection. Remember that a single bite or scratch, even if it is disinfected and bandaged, will strike you ill and kill you no matter what, so don't be cocky and decide to take on an entire herd unless you have a stronghold to take shelter for your dramatic final stand.The goal for me is always the same. Once the game is started, I quickly go out and search for a suitable shelter or stay in the one I have spawned in. Then I shelter-in-place, you know, cover up all the windows and such. I take inventory of my food, then one everything is situated, I go out into the industrial areas of the map to locate three things: An axe, a saw, a hammer, and lots of nails. The idea is to get an axe to chop down the many confiers that grow in the game world, then use the saw to turn them into wooden planks, then use those planks to build walls, doors, and all sorts of useful furniture to hold your important gear. Once the structure of the base is established, I started fixing up a garden. Sometimes I have to move dirt around, usually up on the roof where I don't have to worry about zombies trampling on my crops. I also build my kitchen outdoors, using a campfire as a stove. With the power and water lines being finite resources, it is imperative to get your self-sufficient base established as soon as possible.If you are wondering there are vehicles in this game, then the answer is no, there is no planes, trains, and automobiles in Project Zomboid. Your own two feet is your way in moving around the map. Due to the nature of the game engine, I do not expect to find vehicles in this game anytime soon.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you're tired of the tag "Survival" on Games not living up to their definition, look no more. This is a survival game in the truest definition of the word. With the settings on singleplayer you're able to hone the game exactly to your liking from zombie density to loot rarity all the way down to infection mortality time. A really deep (yet not very upfront) crafting system, a pretty solid building system with other nice features such as cooking recipes (found a frying pan? have some steak and some vegetables? how about a stirfry to raise your mood and get rid of that boredom)The character system is a nice break down as well, you can see exactly where you're injured and take action directly from there whether it be switching bandages, or applying disinfectant directly to a wound. The dev's really take into consideration what the players are suggesting and try to implement ideas the best as possible, it's truly what an early access game should be.There are flaws though, an awkward camera and movement system that takes some getting used to, there's very few tooltips to explain what items can be used for. The game is not very user friendly, you have to do quite a bit of researching either on the Wiki or by trial-and-error, but all in all... it's a real solid early access and besides The Long Dark one of the only TRUE survival games out there.UPDATE: June 2015The expiremental branch is really coming along and the devs continue to deliver on their promises, still one of (if not the) best early access games on Steam.TL:DR -- Very deep survival game, camera takes some getting used to, highly recommended.

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
Early Access Review
								Brilliant zombie game. Blends survival, (real survival) action, simulation, RPG mechanics and of course, zombies. While the zombie genre has been over used to death, (just like that pun) this game really brings something fresh. The greatest aspect is the certainty that you WILL DIE. The real question is when. GraphicsThe graphics are pleasing for me, the style mixes really well and nothing ever sticks out of place except bugs in the art and lighting. The developers are costantly working on this though.MapThe map is set out realisticly and has many locations including lumber yards, farms, wilderness, houses, shops, motels, and more. It is important to mention here that the world is NOT procedurally generated. I think this is good because it makes the world feel far more real and considering how big the developers plan the world to be - it's not going to be a problem.GameplayIf you love survival games, this game will be perfect for you. You can play heaps of different ways and even allows for the "run and gun" tactics which will definitly lead to an untimely end. The developers do stress that if you want to survive long term, you must stay down, sneak around zombies and avoid running - for one scratch could mean zombification. You must keep healthy, scavenge supplies, eat, drink, craft, explore, barricade and heaps more. Keep in mind these are slow zombies, and is tailored for a Romero audience. While you can play sandbox mode and set the zombies to sprinters, this is extremley challenging due to all the other factors you have to survive too,PlannedThere are many planned features, including multiplayer, vehicles, an even larger map, hunting and far far more. I suggest you check the forums for planned features.GripesThe only major gripes I have with this game in its current state is the occasional graphical glitches which can really take you out of the game. Another gripe is the UI glitches. They have recently given their UI an overhaul, and while the new inventory system is amazing, some of the pop up menu's look glitchy.VerdictThis game has the potential to be incredible, even in its current state I could sink hours into it (and have), my lack of game time on my profile is due to me backing this game back in 2011 and I have played many hours of the non-steam version. So, if you love survival zombie games and have a solid zombie apocalypse plan that you want to put into action, this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: April 17
Early Access Review
								Pointlessly detailed simulation that prioritises emulating the boring minutiae of life over having fun.Got a new bag? Great! In most games you'd equip it with one click and your inventory would be expanded. In Project Zomboid you need to unequip the old bag, equip the new bag, put the old bag on the ground, loot the old bag, and have all the contents be transferred across one by one.The goal is realism, but much of the game is just frustrating rather than realistic. What exactly do game developers think tools and weapons are made of? Play-Doh? I think in real life you could poke more than five zombies with a kitchen knife before it broke. There has never been a game that weapon degradation has made better.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								Once upon a time this was a wonderful game. You'd spawn in a random house in a huge map, scavenge the immediate area, spend a few in game months building a giant fortified compound before eventually getting bored, and then close out a wonderful experience with a glorious firearm rampage through the town center.The last few updates took the wind out of the sails. Carpentry skills were rebalanced in such a way that fortified compound building requires the player to grind out way more walls and barricades than any decent sized compound would need just to build up the skill to put a scavenged door in. Game difficulty is either face rollingly easy or wake up to a sea of zombies on your porch every morning annoying with no sweet spot.Firearms aren't fun and don't even function as a panic button. Accuracy sucks at low levels and takes ages to skill up, shotguns can only take out 3 zombies max and that's only likely when firing into a huge crowd, and each shot fired will bring in zombies crazy quick and from long distances. Any situation where discharging a firearm seems like a good idea is a situation already lost.Cars and NPCs will supposedly be implemented at some point (when they're done!) But for now, it just seems as if the game is being balanced for features that don't exist yet and it's not as fun as it once was.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								A real solid survival game that unfortunately ends up falling a bit short due to the huge and arguably broken random factor. Surviving your first couple of days is easy since food is borderline abundant in every house along with water being a common commodity at every tap, toilet and bathtub. Eventually, however, these resources will dwindle, not only by the human consumption but due to the basic services shutting down.Electricity and the Waterworks will abruptly be cut off after some time, leaving any fridge-dependant foods to be almost instantly spoiled, leaving you very dependant on rare canned foods, chips and other conserverd commodities which will run out real fast depending on your character. "Just create a farm!" you say? Fantastic Idea! Just one flaw: You need to find a shovel/trowel and plant seeds. While seeds are rather common, trowel/shovels are not. I have spent countless of hours, killing hundreds of zombies to clear out a big piece of farm-land just to spend even more time searching dumbly for seemingly common tools In order to have any kind of chance to survive. And even then, surviving for any seriously long amount of time won't be possible because your sources of water will run dry faster than you can say "Kebab" as any and all plantations require gigantic sources of water that will need to be hauled back and forth by you, consuming very large amounts of time for little to no actual food seeing how the watering of plants doesn't last for more than half a day or so.But that Isn't even your biggest issue. The method of getting these supplies of water will be unavailable eventually as the city's water works off will turn off. "Just go to a lake!" you say? Nope. No lakes, no rivers and no oceans. Only the very rare 1-2 wells per map which are waaaay outside the actual playing zone/spawn and the only real other way to create a sustainable, although random way of water income is to create rain collection barrels. You'll need Nails, a hammer, a garbage plastic bag and some planks for that.Doesn't sound too bad, right? Wrong. To create planks, you need wooden logs. To create wooden logs, you need to chop down trees... Which you essentially need an Axe for. An even moreso rare item than Trowels and nowhere does this get more annoying than when you search through countless workshops in hope for an axe and Instead get a Saw! "Cut down trees with that"! You say? Nope. Can't do that. You NEED an axe to produce any significant quantities, which comedically enough, has an ingame model of a fireaxe out of all things. No common house-hold hatchets, no making your own improvised axe, no machete or other blunt cutting weapons. You need. An Axe. To produce ANY significant amount of logs. Sure, you can get a good laugh and chop down trees by using a fork If you want to humiliate the already embarassingly stupid sense of logic programmed by the devs but that will take over 200 swings (literally and figuratively slapping a wet blanket up against a tree) but If you're playing said survival game with the promise of It being realistic, it better damn iron out the assigning of item usages and a more realistic loot palette, preferrably designed by someone who doesn't live on an deserted island in the pacific.And as I also described earlier, In one of my playthroughs, I cleared out a huge farmland that had a gigantic harvest of Wheat/Corn in the middle of it, which I couldn't pick. No big deal there, would have been overpowered. Now what I did get frustrated on was another smaller piece of farm land, with fences around it and the ground already being dug up neatly. I cleared the remaining zombies before i eagerly grabbed my seeds and the dozens of water-filled Gardening Spray Cans I found earlier in Workshops/storages and ran out in the dug-up mounds of dirt, standing there like an idiot for minutes on end, trying to figure out just how the game wanted me to put my seeds into the ground before trying all possible combinations, visiting the game wiki and getting a big "F*ck you" finger up in my face on how you NEED a TROWEL/SHOVEL to drop seeds from your hands and into the loose dirt.Adding on a 25+ digit of the previously 40+ houses I searched before reaching the farm, I still ended up with not finding an axe. Not finding a trowel. Not finding a shovel. Nothing. Just more nails, some glue, duct tape and a saw, endlessly taunting me In the face on just what I could have done at my small farmstead in the forest at this point Instead of running around like a complete and utter jackass, struggling to find a specific bent piece of metal so I can put down some seeds on an already processed piece of soil Instead of using my hands, other tools such as hammers that have plowing capacities with the tail, a shoe, an empty soup can, a spoon or my hands. But no, that wouldn't be according to the game logic of this "Simulator". Simply put, If you run to a nearby Workshop and don't get a Shovel/Trowel, a Fireaxe and a Saw, your playthrough already has been signed It's death warrant by none other than the developers.And as I said, Project Zomboid is by all means, a solid game that I also happen to enjoy much personally. but If you look at the on-going 3-4+ years of development time and the current state It is in, one is fair to call it a pile of f*cking rubbish as mods made by lone people in their spare time develop features into this game so much faster than a team of 6 (discluding dozens of associates) fully paid professionals, It's downright frikking embarassing, especially considering the game Is not even 3d, so as of right now, I will unfortunately recommend everyone to avoid this title right now until the developers take the energy they do on advertising updates or explaining why they screwed up on delivering these updates in time and put that effort into making said, promised updates.I would however, recommend to buy It on a sale.UPDATE: The developers have gone out of their way to f√πck the reputation of this title up even more by spending MASSIVE amounts of manpower to integrate user mods into the base game. Yes, that's right. This company that has now been slamming a hammer non-stop for 5+ years on this game has now resorted to spending company time to do less of the sorely needed actual development on the game to force-feed it user made modifications that ANYONE could use at ANY TIME with ANY VERSION of the game OUT OF THEIR OWN FREE WILL prior to this. And to make matters even worse, they have also gone out of their way to start quoting positive Steam user reviews on the store page and have the actual review be consistent of "lol gud geym ei playd a bunhc 10/10 xd" and rightfully so, the reviews they linked have about 25% out of 100% user approval for being ret√°rded.And of course as I recommended to get this game on a sale following my negative review of the game, there has been next to none of them from what I can only presume is only an act of good old fashioned c√≥cky greed at the devs end as Steam now allows any studio to instantly put their products on sale, leaving no marketing excuse as to why not.Avoid this turd like the plague.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is the premier zombie simulator. You'll see a lot of people giving downvotes because of the development length. Or because of "no cars no NPC's"... but sorry guys, those are the most complicated features, and the entire team is not capable of working on them, so they will be the last to come. The game has around 11 devs, and their content output has been consistant. Once you get used to the controls of this game, it will be the most authentic feeling zombie simulator out there. You'll do supply runs, you'll be scared as hordes get‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and you'll struggle to figure out how to cure all the medical problems that can arise in this game. Highly reccomeneded for those that want a deep experience.

I'd like to see NPC's soon so I'll be happy when we get other survivors... as for now though.. New Rating - 10/10 YAY! ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------I once said after spending so much money on Zombie Games and getting no fun that I would never buy a zombie game again, that my zombie game was not out there and no one would probably develop a full hardcore survival game based around zombies... I was wrongI first played this about 2 years ago maybe even 3 and it was on an odd little website inthe dark reaches of the internet and al lthat was available was a linear tutorial. I had to make certain choices during said tutorial to see how long I could survive... naturally I murdered my GF in cold blood as she could not fight back due to I Think a broken leg but I'm not sure... I finally died when I set house on fire cooking (yes that can happen!) After seeing this pop up on steam I decided to give it a buy.. I mean the tutorial was worth it even if I HATE Linear games and well I was pleasantly surprised. The game now has 3 modes including Sandbox where you can choose every single option including what type of zombies you want... naturally I wen't for classic.I survived for a whole hour and that's when I shut it off... I moved on to a mode that was not ulike COD zombies but built within the Project Zomboid engine... it played out very much like the horde mode on Gears of War and it was something I enjoyed most as it allowed me to paly it for 10 minutes at a time!If you are looking for a true action Zomibe survival game then buy this now! I'm giving it a 9/10 but only because its still in development...I'll be sure to upgrade that later on should they turn it into something spectacular.I'm also hoping for Multiplayer soon... Co-Op would be a nice feature and one that would work on so many levels!

content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								NOTE: This is a review I wrote for an Australian computer and technology forum, figured I would post it on here as well, as I think extremely highly of this game. This review isn't exactly written in the style of your standard steam reviews, but it outlines some of the gameplay mechanics and other things in that game make it one of the more enjoyable titles around at the moment, due in part to the multiplayer that is now part of the game.Over the last several years, I've eagerly been watching this game grow and evolve, once in a while I would download the latest build and test it out. Everything was very promising. Here I had a game that offered a True Zombie Apocalypse "Simulator", a game where there is no real goal other than to survive, this was well before games like Day Z started popping up too.Project Zomboid is much different however, first of all the game uses an isometric viewing angle, secondly it tries to "simulate" everything. From cooking, to building to reading books. There are literally hundreds of different items in the game, majority of them have a use. Canned soup can be consumed, but only if you have a can opener, access to a fire or stove and a pot to cook it in. Books can be read to increase your skills in things like fishing, carpentry or farming. All of this takes "time" to do. Your character can be affected by dozens of different things, go out in the rain, you get wet, stay wet for too long, you can get sick. If you're wet, you can change your clothes or dry off with a towel. If you get sick, you can find painkillers and other meds to help you get over it. Get scared by too many zombies and cant find any survivors and your character can start to become panicky and depressed. This is just scratching the surface of what can be done in the game though. The world is persistent, this means you can barricade houses, as long as you have a hammer, nails and some planks, you can cover open windows with sheets so the Zs cant see you inside. Weapons can be repaired with things like Duct Tape or glue, weapons can be modified (not sure how many at this stage have mods) ie. getting a baseball bat and hammering some nails to make it a "nailed baseball bat". You can build doors, doorframes, walls, floors, stairs etc. and essentially build your own fortress, or connect several houses together with wooden walls being used as passageways, so you are safe from the Zs when going between houses. The Zs themselves are quite cool as well, if you play Sandbox or multiplayer mode, you are able to change several different things about the zombies to make them easier or harder, this allows you to customise the Zs to be similar to the ones from your favourite movies (fast, slow, blind/deaf etc) Zombies also give chase, depending on their memory settings, you can lose them just by getting a certain distance away, or you may have to lead them on a merry chase through houses and the bush to make them lose your scent and successfully escape. Combat is fairly standard, however it works great is very satisfying if you get your timing right. There are guns in the game, but majority of the time you will opt for melee weapons, guns will attract zombies, to the point where you can inadvertently attract a horde of 30+ zombies. It makes for some great gameplay and very tense moments. On top of all of this, the game now has multiplayer, at the moment it is join by IP only, so no proper server browser, but once you make/find a server to play in, you will find that the world is persistent, items don't respawn, neither do zombies, zombies will often wander around and may eventually occupying an area that you have previously cleared, but overall this means you can essentially clear out an area and be safe from Zombie Hordes, as they won't respawn once you kill them. This all comes together to create the most enjoyable Co-op experience I have had in as long as I can remember. For $15 on steam, I cannot recommend this game enough. If you still love zombie games, you may find that despite how the game is presented (look at it on the steam store, first reaction is usually that it graphically looks quite dated) it is one of the most feature rich and amazing Zombie Survival games on the market. There is far more that I could list about this great game, but I suggest if it sounds interesting enough from my explanation above, take the plunge and see how you like it. There is also a demo available  which is still quite indicative of what you can expect should you decide to purchase the full game. Seriously guys, get on it.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've bought this game back when it was in Pre-Alpha, and even back then I didn't regret buying, even though back then there was hardly anything to do. But hell, I loved the game back then, and I still do, if it comes to any zombie survival games - this is it. None other game recreates such tactical thinking, such fear of dying as this game does, every step you make you think about the consequences, you think about where you should set your base, and what to do to protect it best, but what made this game even better was for me was the addition of MP, I've waited since alpha for the game to have Multiplayer added to the game, and I always felt like it would change the game completely, and hell, it did. Multiplayer, especially with friends, added this serious survival feel I didn't feel ever before in a game, not in DayZ, nor Rust, nor any multiplayer survival game. You care for your friend in-game, you don't want them to get injured, or worse - bitten, but you also don't want them standing, doing nothing. As a good example, I'd like to share this survivor's story:We all assigned roles to what we'll do, one would take care of the food, another would secure the area of zombies, every once in a while we'd send out people to look for supplies, it was amazing, however, while we grew bigger, we needed better supplies, as well as some shotguns, so we decided to go to West Point, we left our home behind, hoping that we'd come back to it still being in shape...Well, at least most of it.  On the way there one of our friend's condition was getting worse - if we wouldn't find medication, he probably wouldn't make it. On the way there, we tactically dealt with zombies, or sneaked through them,  when the odds were too high, I'd fire a couple of rounds to distract a crowd of zombies, we'd get supplies at a drive-by diner and kept going, but unless we hurried - our friend wasn't going to make it, and sadly, he didn't, and it meant more than in any game, and that, is what I'd call a true survival experience. You cared that your friend died, with that one less man, not only do your possibilities go down, but so do your chances go down, every bullet you take, took and will take will make an impact, and a brilliant idea done poorly will cause the death of your team, and this is what I love about the game. While playing it, I felt like I was in some weird mix between The Last Of Us, The Walking Dead and something like Fallout, as amazing as it might be...However, I really think that there should be more of a 'leveling' system, since, even though you do have a bunch of skills to level, if you die, you quickly shake it off, I hope that the devs add something that would make you more attached to your character than you are now.Project Zomboid is packed with features and things to do and a lot of places to go to, there are a ton of items, and a ton of items to craft, but some currently don't have any use, as mentioned, this game is still fairly early in the development, some features that aren't in the game may be fairly important to survival, for example, a generator, that you'll need to get electricity from when the power runs out, luckily water barrels are buildable, so you won't dehydrate when you run out of water. But those are some things to keep in mind.The game is very stable right now, there are a few bugs, which is to be expected, considering the game isn't finished, but I'd recommend this game to anyway, since this game is made purely from passion and talent, and it has to be one of my favourite survival singleplayer games, and one of the best (if not the best) of survival multiplayer games, and it ain't even finished yet!

content:
Posted: April 17
Early Access Review
								Project Zomboid is more of a simulation than a game. Perhaps it's supposed to be? For me, there are far too many components and you spend half your time sorting your inventory so as not to be overburdened. The other half of your time is spent reading books, and picking items off the floor which you accidentally dropped. Picking up 50 seeds one by one from the ground is not my idea of good gameplay. And what is this obsession in new games with degrading weapons? It's never been a fun idea to have your favourite weapon stop working. I don't think the "line of sight" rule works when you have a 3rd person game, especially in multiplayer where your mate will disappear if behind you. Yes, you can't see what's behind you in real life, but you can be aware.This game/simulation feels like a chore, which is disappointing, given how good the premise is.Oh and it needs cars.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Honestly, I originally found this game quite bland. My fondest memory was spawning in the house, finding and drinking bleach, walking out of the house and then falling over dead. I didn't play it too much after that.BUT, they recently unleashed online test to the public, at which point my friend immediately set up a server for us and we were away on our adventure. As I am typing this, we have been playing for a solid 3 hours, many notable moments being burning down several houses, barricaded a warehouse, and having friends go out scavenging for supplies while I cooked at home. This is the game that many zombie survival games tried to be (Such as DayZ, which contrary to popular belief was developed long after this game was started). This game gets all of the feels that a zombie survival game should. Instead of immediately searching for weapons to kill zombies with, you always have thoughts in the back of your head as to: Will we have enough food? Will we have time to cook some good food to keep everyone from getting depressed? Did I turn the stove off?While playing, our favorite thought was having a server that would be able to run 200 players at the same time. Think of the communities that would start with the fact that you can build walls and even houses from scratch, and with the proper tools you can tear down other houses for supplies. Needless to say, I have never been more excited for the future of a single game until now. I feel that anyone who likes tense survival with friends should play this game. This game is, as all 4 of us agreed, is DayZ done right.TL:DR DayZ but not rushed, with similar ideas of Fallout and The Sims.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have played this game offline for over 100 hours. Listen, all these zombie games do something right. Zomboid, does a lot of things right, but if they aren't what you're looking for, you may not like this game.This game Is NOT a FPS death match with enough gun types to overthrow a small slavic nation. This is a game about a random, everyday Kentuckian that got caught up in the zombie appocolypse. If you like zombies and you like serious, intense survival, this game is for you.As it is right now, this game offers challenges that will frustrate you and keep you on your toes. There is the threat of Zombie Hordes, sickness, starvation and making that one freaking mistake that makes you start over. Play this game if you want a true challenge and actually feel like you accomplished something when you survive a few months. But what really makes this game worth buying is the potential it has.The map is already huge and they are going to make it even bigger. They are going to add Metro Louisville into the game map which will be incredible.The crafting system keeps getting better and they are adding more and more customization.NPCs and Cars are coming at some point and will take this game to cult-classic type levels on par with Crusader Kings 2 but for zombies. Buy this game. Be patient. Learn2Play and enjoy! Even if you buy it now and wait till NPCs come out, it will be worth it. Potentially one of the greatest games in it's niche even as it stands now.

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								I very much recommend this game for anyone who:a) Likes tense, realistic zombie games;b) Wants a game that feels more like a movie (i.e. Dawn of the Dead) than dynasty warriors (i.e. Dead Rising);c) Doesn't mind a game being unpolished (e.g. currently no NPCs in the build I am playing).The game is extremely compelling, even if a little thin on the ground for content.  You must grit your teeth and carve out some space for your character to call 'home'.  Barricade the doors, shut the curtains, create a sheet rope to access the second floor window.  Then get building your perimeter wall and planting your crops.  Don't forget rain collectors.  Now you have the basics of survival, you can make forays into the dangers of the city, staying in cleared out houses along the way and making sure to attract as little attention as possible.This game has the potential to leave a huge, huge indent on future zombie games, probably the same way DayZ has already done.  When NPCs and multiplayer are added (especially LAN which would be incredible), this could become the FTL of the zombie genre.Considering I have got 30 hours of fun from this game, I would say that it's definitely worth ¬£5.  In terms of ¬£10, it's your choice: either wait until the game is a little more advanced and REALLY get your value, or jump in and support the developers early on and enjoy running around a town full of 4500 zombies with no NPCs.Right now I would rate this game a compelling 7/10 but it has the potential to hit 9 or 10/10.For reference here is how I rate other non-arcade zombie games:Resident Evil 4: 9/10TellTale Games The Walking Dead: 8.5/10Left 4 Dead: 8.5/10Resident Evil 2 or 1: 8.5/10Left 4 Dead 2: 7.5/10Dead Island: 7/10Dead Rising: 7/10The Last of Us: 7/10DayZ (currently): 6/10 (with the potential to be much higher)Dead Rising 2: 5/10As you can see I have left a space at the top for 9.5 and 10/10.  Reason being there has never actually been a zombie game that lives up to the tension, excitement and cloying exigency for survival that permeates the finest zombie movies.Project Zomboid does have a chance to reach that level or somewhere near it.  The fact that the merest scratch can but not necessarily will turn you eventually into a zombie is a welcome change to the superhero melee murder spree that many other zombie games offer.  The fact that you can die of hunger, thirst, regular disease and being soaked to the bone by freezing rain adds tension.  Your crops can die of diseases, a horde of zombies can shamble up to your safehouse and lay siege to it.  Firing your gun attracts three times as many zombies as you originally intended to engage.So there you have my take on this charming, albeit incomplete, little game.
