Early Access Review
								What can I say about Project Zomboid ?  I love this game.It's hard to survive in the zombie apocalypse but everything starts to make sense and you start to feel comfortable.You gather food supplies and barricade a house, your skills are building up.Everything is fine, then you're checking a house and you casually open a bathroom door and go in without looking and . .  There's three zombies in there that munch or your arm before you can get away.You put a ripped sheet on it to stop the bleeding but it get's infected because the bandage wasn't disinfected.Over 2 days you get weaker and weaker and then you die.This is just one of the many deaths I've had in this game.If you buy this game, your character will die too and that's the fun !It's not about whether you die or not, it's about what you did while you were alive.

								     One of the best zombie survival games I have  ever played. The game has some major performance issues and an immense amount of bugs but keep in mind this game is still fairly new. The player must survive for as long as he can by looting houses and not being killed by zombies. If you do happen to buy this game and you get a black screen upon loading a new character right click the game in steam and go to: Properties -> set launch options -> and type "-safemode", or you could also try the compatibility mode option upon launching the game!

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								Development? Yeah, it's slow. It's also early access. By buying, you're acknowledging that it may never be finished. I did. I like to think that I got my $15 worth, and will get more than that with every update, regardless of the time it takes the team to get the updates out. I have the utmost respect for the devs, putting up with all the crap a lot of folks are putting them through in terms of how long updates take. By now, if I were TIS, I'd go the route of, say, Interstellar Marines and just leave everyone in the dark to shut most of them up so I could work. But, instead each week they put on their gloves and get ready for the **** that gets slung their way because they choose to keep us in the loop.Now that I'm done with that, on to gameplay.Even in its current state, in the off chance of zombacaylpse, I've learned a lot from PZ. Stockpile water in anything that can hold water. Turns out the people that keep the water running stop going to work after the world ends. Keep some books and toys handy (the toys may be part of the Hydrocraft mod, I'm not sure). Boredom is nobody's friend. Stockpile food, obviously. Non-perishables don't grow on trees, unfortunately, and besides, you're gonna cut all the trees down to make walls and other things. Perishables perish shortly after the power shuts off, too. Learn how to grow food. It's a marketable skill during the end of the world.And when the animations update arrives, you're probably going to want several changes of clothes rather than wearing that one sweat shirt and that one t-shirt for the rest of your life. Blood stains and all.I think it's worthy of the "something in my eye" award because you will get attached to your character and all the progress you make with him or her. You'll have killed lord knows how many deadoes, and then, when you least expect it, the sound of your flesh being torn open by a rotting hand or a decayed jaw. You suddenly aren't long for the world. You spent so long trying to ride out the storm, only to become a part of it. You think back to the first one you killed, then the first building you cleared. Staring in horror at that first house you saw boarded up, filled with rotters trying to break out and devour your flesh. Fast forward to the lights going out, or the water shutting off, and wondering How will I survive now? and finding a way. And for however long you kept finding a way, beating in heads, looting the homes of the deceased, fortifying your home (whatever or where-ever it may be). And now you flash forward to just a moment ago, as Rodney Rot-Face there just took a bite out of your arm. You are not long for the world now, and with this realization, and perhaps a tear in your eye, you can decide to hole up and wait to die, or you can take revenge on the world that did this to you.Be lovely, I'm out, dropping the mic!

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								No real easy multiplayer options yet, unless you join neglected servers.  They exist, and it is possible to host a server, but awkward for a computer novice.  BUT, a very fun adventure that captures the essence of isolation, desperation, and determination inherent in a survival experience.  The fact that there are zombies just gives a backdrop.  A lot of little details that leave you with a robust and lovingly-crafted world to explore.  This game has medications such as beta-blockers, sleeping aids, painkillers, and even vitamins.  Name another game with that.Also, there seems to be a lot of active development and mod content from the community.  I'm not certain how much longer the challenge of existing will keep me occupied in a single player experience, but I can certainly envision this game's development will bring me back periodically to enjoy the new content.Would buy again.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								Project Zomboid is hands down my favourite sandbox survival simulator, primarily because you can tell the devs are just hardcore genre fans. The atmosphere of doom looming really brings out a horror game. It's like the game is telling you in advance: you will fail.Atmosphere is great.Updates are actively coming, so the game is not stagnant. Community is healthy and engaged, the devs are actively engaged with their players.The game itself really fits the old control style I personally like. Some would call it dated for not using 50 shortcut keys for everything, but I happen to like the mouse driven context menu interface.Music is superb. Setting is superb, and generic enough to craft any roleplay scenario the admin desires. What's best - the multiplayer option to run a dedicated server.Great job, Indie Stone!

There are no arrows pointing you anywhere, or time limit, or kill objective to accomplish, it is simply you in the mist of a zombie apocalypse trying to gather supplies and build up a base. This is one ride you have to take if you truly call yourself a zombie fan.

content:

Early Access Review
								Alt-tabbed to look up some crafting instructions. Logged back in to find I'd starved to death. My cabbage farm shall live on for all eternity. 10/10.In all seriousness, this is a really solid game. Don't let the retro graphics or early access fool you - yes, it has it's bugs, it's flaws and a lot of content still to come, but you can easily pour hours into this game, especially in coop. The attention to detail around the perk system, base-building, sound travelling, etc. is a sign this developer knows what they're doing and it's a really nice example of a zombie-survival game taking a slightly different tack from the rest of the pack.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								I feel like this is one of the only zombie survival games with actual active developers. They keep the community up to date and release updates consistently. I also feel like they can do way more with the game/engine as well. As for gameplay, it's fun at first, but some things can get stale after a while. This will force you to play differently and explore your options. As of now, you can make a base, farm crops, and fish. Water and electricity will shut down after a period of time, forcing you to rely on yourself for resources. Fighting zombies is fun, yet very risky. All it takes is one scratch or bite to become infected. I thought the multiplayer had potential, but I wasn't a huge fan of the execution. Joining a server for the first time can be difficult depending on what kind of server it is. There isn't a lot of food, and chances are enough time has passed for water and electricity to be nonexistent. I think this game shines most with singleplayer and co-op, and the addition of promised npcs will make it twice as much fun. Definitely a good game for the price. If you put it down for a while, you'll probably come back to 2 or 3 updates to explore.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								Ok so let's do some math here, 760k units sold. Currently the flat price is 15 dollars. At release it might have been cheaper. Just to make the numbers nicer, let's reduce the price to 10 dollars, and the units to 700k and they still made 7 MILLION DOLLARS. Even if we take out 2 million or whatever the deal is with steam, it's more than enough to hire full time worker at 80k+ a year and still have money left over? I just cannot fathom that this game has been in early release for what? 4 years soon. No animations, no NPCs and plenty of gliches to be had and missing content. I guess since the bulk of the money was already made from the people who actually wanted to play the game. People who actually wanted to help and see the game grow gave money up to buy and play it, whilst the developers run off with their money. Insane. It just feels like 2012-2013 was the game a bunch of these indie developers made these zombies survival games and released unfinished games as early access, made their money and dropped the project because how much more money would they be making if the game was finished?Just think Day-Z as an example, sold at 35 dollars  but it's l;iterally a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ier looking arma 2/3 with even ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ier looking zombies and AI. lmao

								The zombie survival genre. A wasteland full of FPS games that all go similar ways. it all feels like some mish-mash of minecraft and a unique idea or two. Then theres project zomboid... a stand-out title that doesn't use those crappy "WE'RE DEAD NOW THATS WHY WE CAN RUN REALLY F*CKING FAST NOW" mentality. this is classic, george romero style zombies, they aren't a simple annoyance, that in hordes are dangerous. One encouter with a zombie could mean the end of years of hardwork and gameplay. Even though it has a static map, every game seems diffrent. are you gonna spawn in a house with a good weapon? Do you have to tread the streets welding a measly spoon as your weapon of choice? Rember Zomboid does NOT play around, from the start the game makes sure you know it ain't screwin aroundAll I want you to take out of this review is that Zomboid is an amazing survival game that really does ask the question, will you survive the zombie apocalapse?Also these devs are f*cking awesome, I always play on the opt-in builds and I rarely notice a bug. Do note, this game is not going to be done any time soon. Though that is to be expected with a four man team.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								Aside from being one of the most open-ended zombie apocalypse simulators in gaming, this masterpiece is nothing short of amazing.Right off the bat - is the game challenging? You are encouraged to use the game's tools to tailor-make your own version of the apocalypse, editing zed rules, environment weather and loot rates. Does everyone reanimate with the zed disease? Do the zombies in your apocalypse break whatever is in their way, or will they only attempt to infiltrate if they are chasing a noise? Are the zombies never ending, or is there a set population spread out across Kentucky?Once you have set your parameters you are dropped in as the stock character you have set up, choosing from a wide variety of previous jobs and traits, each with their own effect and skill boosts (this gets even juicier with multiplayer as you will be playing with people with different abilities and central skills).Your build can range from a burger flipper with an iron-gut and thick skin to a brave firefighter with additional first-aid skills to a desensitized war veteran with an eagle eye.Once you spawn in, you will be in what was presumably your home with randomly generated loot. You have the keys to the place, but are not forced to live there. What will you do? Will you take what's in the kitchen and live off of whatever meal you can throw together until you need to leave? Will you take everything you can with you as you search for a better place to live? Will you leave the stove on and burn your house down with you in it? This is Project Zomboid, and this is the story of how you died.Aside from being a fun and challenging game to play on your own or with friends, Project Zomboid is pretty good for seeing how well you could potentially take care of yourself in a situation where society's rules are out of the window. Compare your current life to how your story began in Project Zomboid. Did you always have somebody who could cook for you? Did you not bother to learn anything about basic carpentry? What skills do you have? You are only yourself, and you can't do everything great (or even good enough) off the bat. So what will you do? Either way, you will have to learn new things. But what skills do you plan on using? Do you have a friend you can work with who can help take a load off? Are you going to be on the run solo until you can predict the dangers you may run into?If you can micromanage your character to ensure that you can maintain a healthy diet with no health complications or depression months past the power dies, odds are you are doing something right in your plan. And if you are at that point and are surviving off of worms and anti-depressants, you must really hate yourself.From camping under the stars to camping on the roof, the options for staying alive are endless. Do what suits you best. You may not be a carpentry/electrical based character. Maybe you are a park ranger? Use your herbology knowledge to forage for medical herbs, and set up camp somewhere deep in the woods. Not so good with the outdoors, but are even better than most with a baseball bat and are in the shape of your life? Maybe living on the move or in a safer suburban area could do you good. Great with a hammer, but not so great at fighting zombies? Construct a perimeter and use your skills to maintain it.And again, I can not stress how much better this game gets on multiplayer. Having a group of friends with different central skills and profession benefits will create it's own dynamic and let you fully experience everything the game has to offer.

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								TL:DR;Possibly most complex zombie survival out there, despite it's granularity I cannot recommend it without few warnings.First, it has been in Early Acces for like what? 3 years? Development come to nearly a stop. For the other reasons, read on.Review:Project Zomboid is complex zombie postapolacyptic survival game. Name 'dwarf fortress' can come to a mind for quite a few reasons. Reason one - number of small things and items and map size.Reason two - never ending development and bugsGameplay in this game is very uneven and under designed. You start as a survivor in one of the locations on a VERY large map. From there on, you have to cloth yourself, eat, drink, creaft weapons and kill zombies. Sounds good? After all who woudn't like good old zombie killing and survival combo?The problems however can break even the greatest enthusiasm.So let's name them.Starting new game - there is no real tutorial, except for very basic movement. Worse, sandbox settings are so uneven, that it beggets belief. On weak setting zombie takes 4 hits of crowbar. On normal, 12. How much it takes on strong?Numbers of zombies on survival setting is so huge, you will constantly bump into groups of 10-20 zombies.On basic perception settings they will spot you on sight. On basic speed setting they will keep following you everywhere. There is no story line to follow. Except some gibberish new feed on TV. No notes to be found (there is even a mod that adds them!). No NPCs to save and care for. Absolutelly no point in doing anything no reason for you to keep going. No achievements. Not even a sense of achievement, if you manage to put up a decent base.But lets back to ur zombies, mkay? Oh and I see that Random Event just spawned a horde after us?Now, maybe it's time to fight back? There are no real weapons to craft. What you find is usually crap, best of weapons being axe, which is also critical to crafting. And items do wear out!Guns - they miss most of the time, and draw more zombies. Swinging your axe at them will get you swarmed or will eat your stamina and get you swarmed.There are little traps, bombs, etc.Worse is that on hardcore setting you can't just shot your gun. You have to load, rack it, aim and shoot. I believe that complexity is welcome, but there are reasons why in games you do certain things by yourself automaticaly.So maybe let's build a base to put up a wall between us and zombies. Suprise - you can't. Once you level up carpentry so that you actually can, you discover that cutting trees exhausts you after 3 trees. And they overburden you. And you have to carry them to the place where you build and drop them on the ground. Only to discover, ground level has capacity limit(whaat?) to a maximum 5 wood logs per tile.And once you build the wall you suddenly discover zombies will simply swarm it and keep bashing it untill it breaks.There are no stone walls to build, no steel reinforced barricades, only wooden crap that lasts few minutes against the zombies. There is not real base building. No real sense of reward after tremendous work it takes to fortify anything. Mkay, but perhaps we can craft something otherwise usefull?No, despite having tons of crap. You can't attach a knife to the mop and make a spear. You can't upgrade your pistol with a stock to make it more accurate, put a flashlight on it to see in the dark etc. Predefined mods are very few.Top line craftable weapon is spiked baseball.Something else maybe? Like what? Radio, that doesn't reach anywhere? To add insult to injury, Inventory management is troubling, at least. There are very few slots to put anything in, two hands, chest, legs, boots, backpack slot. Nothing else. No careful arming and protecting youself. FFS damn wound system points to more slots than you can actually equip something to!Ok, so the basic game is bland and pointless. Maybe mods will help?Yes, there are certain mods that do improve the game. For example burning corpses in the fire mod. Or different book colours to help you tell them apart. Or perhaps more zombie loot - finally they carry something more than just clothes. But some mods add things that are completelly pointless. Biggest one, called Hydrocraft, allows you to establish an entire  industry. But ask yourself this:In zombie survival game, wouldn't you like to be able to craft solar panels to heat water and cook food rather than build a mine and cast tin ingots?Perhaps you would like to make a solid spear instead of bronze halebard?What about putting leather wraps around your legs and arms, rather than cast steel morning star?You see. Adding few hundred recipes that are useless unless playing with people in multiplier, which isn't working quite good, doesn't help. Knowing all the above you have to make a hard decision wheter to support a game from Early Access limbo with your money. After 55h hours of my gameplay I feel like I have achieved completely nothing. Make sure you will not make the same mistake.Edit:Also, keep in mind. Devs were seen arguing with negative reviewers in steam comment section. I sh!t you not!

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7
Early Access Review
								Don't let the outdated poisitve fool you, it's a facade of what used to be. Pretty depressing. There's only a few games out there these days that really utilize early access to strive. Starbound was a prime example, the game hits early access, the developers keep on a rampant grind, and then the game is released. Top of the line, A++ quality game.Zomboid was going to be my second on the list. The early access was amazing, I was playing with friends, having a great time, coming back every now and then when big updates would come up, but always waiting for specific promised features. I know it's early access, that's why I gave them years on years to add them, and it didn't bother me. However after a while, it became clear to me that the development team had changed.I'd say from 2 years back now, the development hit a halt. Vehicles have only been remotely announced recently, but for years were in the silent. The promised NPCs / Bandits were rarely mentioned again, and the building system was still as buggy as day one. But through all of the bugs, And then the weekly/monthly news releases and dev blogs would come out. ANIMATIONS. That's it. No feature updates, no vehicles, no multiplayer tweaks, rarely any potent bug fixes, and no AI. What was their latest update? Animations."We redid the animation system""New animations coming out""We've been working on animations for months""These new animation tweaks are golden"2 years. They had 2 years of money and development, and the only progress we were seeing - was on animations. The game, admiteddly, didn't have the smoothest animations - so I get why they would want to overhaul them in preperation for a full release. 2 Years though? Really?And then every other dev blog had an excuse for these animations."We have a new team helping us out""Here's our new animator""We encountered some bugs"It was all nonsensical excuses to deliberately extend the moneygrab before they'd abandon the project. And it's clear that was the direction they were going in.The biggest factor to take in right here, is that out of all of the updates in the past 2 years - you won't notice a majority of them. The bugs never affected anyone, half of the QoL fixes weren't needed, and the interface updates were honestly worse. If you update a game over 2 years and people can't notice the changes, it is a clear sign that priority needs to change.If you are wondering why a game with "very positive reviews" has extremely negative reviews suddenly, it is because this is a practically ABANDONED GAME. If you like it for the stage it's in now, then by all means buy it. However if you expect vehicles, AI, or reliable multiplayer changes - DON'T BUY THIS. You will not see those updates during your play time. It will take atleast another 1-2 years to maybe see these? But by then I am convinced the team will have abandoned the project.Sadly, as much as I was rooting for this to not be "another stereotypical abandoned early access project", it is. It's just that. Just like every other early access money grab. And it's a shame, because it was such a good game. It was turning out to be an isometric DayZ and it was AWESOME. But now it's just a joke. A wasteland of abandoned code and failed promises.Save your money and invest it into some other completed games or upcoming projects. Find a more reliable team to put your hope into. This team will take your money and run with it. Don't trust them, or any of the developer blogs they release. They will lie to their customers - no hesitation. And if you speak out against them, they will do whatever they can to silence you, hide your posts, and mask your thoughts.Don't fall for this scam. Please.

number of helpful: 33 of 59 people (56%) found this review helpful8 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								I bought this game way back in Xmas 2013. While it had potential it was a visually ugly, buggy experience.Fast forward nearly two years and I returned after reading about the new visual engine and changes to the default Survival mode. Now I think it's one of the best early access games around (since Kerbal left the EA stable).Anyway you live in Knox County (an absolutely massive map btw) which has a couple of substantial towns, out of town mega-mall (go there if you want to die) and many other out of the way locales.I really can't be bothered writing any more here. Just trust me (how could you not!) that this is a beast of a game with many levels of gameplay (medicine, crafting, cooking etc..) to keep you interested. Game can be played as pure roguelike by creating a new world each time you die, or - what I do - roguelite by having the next character spawn in the pre-existing world and recovering your old safe house and inventory.The downside to playing the same world with a new toon is that by then you will be a month or two into the apocalypse. What this means is NO ELECTRICITY, NO WATER, MANY FOODSTUFF SPOILED and an expanded Zombie population.Just try the game, or wait till it leaves early access. Either way it doesn't bother me because I don't know you and if I did, I probably wouldn't like you enough to be steam friends and travel the world in MP together. Don't be sad about that, you'll find "FUN" in this game even without me.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								i love this game i do think you should watch some youtube videos to see if its your type of game. at first glance the graphics might turn you off, but stick with it the game and crafting and survival aspect is more then in depth enough that you dont even notice. even without mods like hydrocraft there are so many building and crafting options to survive. i also like the costum sandbox options you can even pick the zombie build ( how fast they move, how strong, even how zombification is transmitted or not transmitted, also how long you have before you turn) i love zombie games i have so many and this one is a new fav this is a true zombie SURVIVAL game, by that i mean your worst enemy in this game isnt always the zombies. its the rain making you wet and get sick, or its not having food orwater when the water and power go off. or its that cut you got breaking into a house to loot. there are many many moodlet bubbles in this gaem that add a sense of realism to the game. the maps are pre set meaning they are Not random, usually i dont like this as you get to used to the map and the game replayability is lessened but this map is so huge it would take me hours in real time to make it across this map even longer if you count having to stop to eat and drink and rest so the fixed map you will have trouble getting bored of. and if you do there are several additional maps in the workshop that just add small towns right to the existing map expanding on it. there is so much to offer with this game that from what i see anyways doesnt have alot of glitches that i have experienced. there are so many ways to play this game. stay in town and be a looter or move out to the more wooded areas and start a farm. saying that id like to say im super impressed with the farming system that offers things like different water requirments for different plants, fertilizer even making mildew or other plant cures to care for your farm. the stat and lvling system is a hard grind unless you find books to read to give you xp multipliers but i love the hunting for books or magazines that have new recipies i havent found yet. this game is a good option for those who love their zombie games but want a more realistic apocalyse then a shoot 'em up zombie game like left for dead (also awesome fyi)the building reminds me of the sims sort of the looting hmm like dead island or dying light in terms of lots of junk items or less used items but there is so much content this is really a game worth some attention even if the first glance reminded me of a game id played in the 80s or early 90s this game definatly did more then impress me as this is my first review i felt compelled to make. for an early access game this game is heading down the right path to be a very successful game. the developers appear to be attentive and care about feed back and concerns from the players. if your thinking about it try the demo you may want to play the demo a few times as you play as a bitten character so you have 2-3 in game days to play but it will give you a short idea of the rough game play though the demo doesnt really give the game justice it really helped me make my choice to buy this game. the online multiplayer function is also makes this game even better, i enjoy playing this game with others the servers make the game even more realistic. as you can go it alone or find a group or partner to survive and thrive with. on the other side on a pvp server you can do the same or just be a bandit or form a gang and kill other survivors to get their gear the choice is yours in Project ZomboidNovember, 27, 2016I have to say this game continues to improve and the relationship with the customers and the modding community is excellent there are so many mods for this game you can really make it a very personalized zombie survival experience...how will you die?

content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Probably the best example of appropriate direction for a zombie apocalypse survival game.  Bleak and ominous, emphasized by the game's beautiful musical soundtrack.  Loss of character for failure helps drive a sense of permanence and weight to the world, a trait decidely lacking in most other titles.However, the environments are largely bland and uninteresting.  The basic mechanics are relatively easy to master, and the game offers no escalation in challenge.  The UI is clunky at best, often feeling needlessly cumbersome.  It attempts to employ RPG elements in the way of independently leveling skills, but then perplexingly ties them back to a master level.Fun for a bit, but quickly runs out of things to show.

content:
Posted: February 13
Early Access Review
								I purchased this game roughly 5 years ago at a time when there actually was NPCs; dysfunctional, unintelligible NPCs but still. This was a time before it was even on Steam and I had to get grandfathered into the Steam download.I was hooked on the potential but soon after the NPCs were yanked and have not been seen again. They had an extremely ambitious scope for what they were planning to do with NPCs; something they referred to as a meta-game which simulated thousands of NPC interactions outside the players own experience. They promised a lot. After well over 5 years of development I cant help but feel cheated.Unfortunately, the only feedback I can give at this time is that the development team, which consists of several people, is atrocious. Every now and then I re-install the game only to find a game that is nowhere near finished with an incredible amount of bloat in several areas causing a strange imbalance. The maps are huge, numerous and lifeless. The amount of objects, especially food, is extroardinary. The team has a habit of investing months of time in something arbitrary that doesnt appear to focus on finishing the project. The combat and UI are having trouble finding their identity. The game doesn't really play well with either a joystick or a keyboard/mouse as the inventory system and combat dont complement each other fluidly.Over the years, I have carefully observed the progress of the game so far and let me tell you if those years are any indication for the pace at which they work, we will be waiting another 5-10 years before they add NPCs and finish the game. Ironically, the amount of updates on their website is consistent in the form of what they call "Mondoids" and often times pretty lengthy despite there not being much progress. In their defense, I will say that the game is actually really fun for a minute and light years ahead of many indie projects, but the lack of any structure quickly dissolves the game into boredom. Im beginning to feel as if the team cashed out and are putting minimal effort to maintain the status quo.Im going to recommend that you dont purchase until they provide a finished product.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								I don't remember exactly when I first bought this game (long before it arrived on Steam), but it was at least 7 years ago.Very little seems to have changed since then. They spent two years working on a whole new game engine and map tools, which perhaps was of long term benefit, but what have they done in the other 5 years? Added some crafting and farming (fair enough, good), multiplayer (could have waited in favour of other stuff), redid interfaces, stats and other minor stuff.If you buy the game, you will get some enjoyment out of it for a while. You'll enjoy exploring the town, breaking in to various buildings and searching for useful stuff to help you survive, dodging or fighting off zombies along the way. You'll enjoy trying to build your zombie proof home.And then you'll get bored of it. The developers might keep you interested in how the development is going with their weekly essays on how awesome the game is going to be once they add the extra features that they've been working on for the last X years, but even that will wear thin sooner or later.If you're bored and want a distraction for a little while, then perhaps buy this and play it until you get bored again. But don't buy it based on promised content or improvements 'cos it'll be years away, if it arrives at all.Edit: For those questioning my time frame. I moved house about 5 years ago, and I played Zomboid at least a year or two before that, back when it was using Java (before the change of game code/engine, as stated above). Long before Steam EA (as stated above), so don't bother quoting that at me.Plenty of other games just as complex have been fully developed on EA and released in that time, so the argument "development takes time", yes it does. But for someone who has been following this game on and off for so long, this is just getting silly.Give it a couple more years, we'll see if you're still as zealous then.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								I had heard a lot about this game on Reddit, and it eventuallly sparked enough of my interest to make this the very first early-access/alpha/beta game I have purchased on steam. I have stayed up until 6am playing this.If you like isometric, survival/crafting, zombie, adventure, rpg games, then you will absolutely love Project Zomboid!For an isometric game, the aesthetics are fantastic! The detail put into the environment is great, and the building/wall camera vision style will switch automatically, allowing you to always see your character (think Sims style) - unless, of course, you are being swarmed by zombies. There is also a great field of vision mechanic where you can only see in a cone radius in front of your character - so you can turn around to see a zombie standing right next to you (this game has prompted many screams from me lol). The music is perfect for the inensity of the game, of every single moment where it can be your last.The controls can take a little bit of getting used to, especially considering that you have multiple menus to deal with (ex: inventory, character stats). You have the option of keeping the menus locked open, making looting much faster if you can handle the space each menu takes up on the screen. There is a lot you can do in PZ, and it is highly recommended that you keep the unofficial map handy for quick reference. The game allows you to choose your profession, which will grant skills like higher resistance to zombie bites and scratches. You can also balance perks and negative skills, making the game more interesting. The custom mode provides a way to test out the game, allowing you to select the frequency of encountering zombies, their overall stats, how long until the electricity and water supply run out (yes, this is a critical element of the game), etc. If you want to get a good feel of the game, I recommend you start of here, just so you can better understand what you need to do without the pressure of dying at a moment's notice.The learning curve and difficulty of this game is moderate, however, I would consider survival mode (how the game is meant to be played) to be fairly hard. You will start off at in a random house, with only the clothes on your back. From here, you can loot supplies, hopefully finding some sort of bag item - which you can wear on your back, increasing your carrying capacity. Securing food and water is essential. Any container objects like bowls or bottles can be used to hold water from the sink, and this is critical to remember because the water supply will eventually run out. Perishable food will rot when not refrigerated.You increase in proficiencies as you do certain things - for example, whever you sneak around zombies you will gain points in nimblness, sneaking, etc. When you attain enough xp points, you will be able to "master" the first level of a "completed" skill. So, if I have cooked enough meals to fill my first block on the skill menu (level 1), and have a level up point, I can select the skill, mastering it and improving the quality of things that I cook. You will not be able to fill higher level skill blocks until you first master the lowest tier - this prevents you from just cooking for the entire game since you have to be mastering each level as you progress. Reading specialty books also provides a bonus multiplier to the respective skill, and there are different books for both skills, and their respective levels (ex: carpentry for begineers vs. advanced carpentry). While you play, you will have to balance your needs, eating, sleeping, and staying hydrated. You can also get bored if you are inactive, and becoming unhappy is also a possibility (leads to depression). There are items you can take to help with these needs (like beta pills, antidepressants, reading newspapers, etc), and you can also take sleeping pills to allow you to go to bed (you cannot keep sleeping unless your character is actually tired) - this is very useful for trying to settle sleeping patterns into a rhythm where you are sleeping during night time and awake in time to maximize the daylight visibility. The crafting is not too complex, you will need to find an axe and chop down trees for logs, then convert them into wood. Crafting a rain collector is a priority - with successfully finding an area to plant/farm as a close second. I have played this game a lot, and there was one time when I had spent 3 hours securing a base and building nice walls around it. I even had set up a farm and rain barrel, with pretty decent skills leveled up already. While looting a nearby house, I opened a window, but the alarm went off. Being overconfident in my abilities, I went in anyway, thinking I would be able to loot and leave before the house was stormed by zombies. While looting the upstairs rooms, I heard the door break open. I quickly run down and spot zombies rushing in through the front door. I try the back door, but zombies are piling in from a broken window next to the fridge. Panicking, I run upstairs, loot a shirt, tear it into sheet rope, and fashion a climbable rope on the second-level window. I slide down, but zombies are surrounding the house, and I have no way out. I hop over a broken window on the first floor and attempt to juke through the zombie horde. I take a scratch, and immediately see that I am about to die. I try to drop my bag, but it is too late. I have joined the dead.I stare at the screen for a good 2 minutes, sigh sadly, then load up a new game.I love this game.If you load a save where you have died, everything you have done will remain intact, so securing and transforming a safehouse will not be wasted. You can even find your corpse walking around if you are lucky. The mod support is not as extensive as say, Space Engineers or Starbound, however, there is a lot of potential for great user-made content. The developers, unlock Starbound, are also very active, releasing builds at good intervals. Be warned, however, not to invest to much in your saves, as you may not be able to transfer over your saves to newer builds when they are released.If you are interested at all, give this game a try. For an early-access game, it is quite impressive and very well-done.Highly recommend!

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								Project Zomboid is one of those few gems that is released every 5-7 years, where should I begin this review? Let's start with the concept of the game. The whole idea of PZ is to survive as long as possible, there are no objectives,  no end goal, just survive. Now this may sound easy, but in a world full of zombies constantly out to get whatever they smell/hear/see this can become rather challenging. We all know what zombies are and do, they are dead corpses that were reanimated by some sort of virus or disease and now out to infect everything in sight. And if you're an avid zombie hunter, then this game may sound like just another game with zombies in it, it's not.Let's get to the actual gameplay elements;Crafting: You can literally build what ever type of base you want, now this is by far one of the coolest features, you can wall off entire city blocks if you wanted to. (that would require quite a bit of resources though, I'll get to that in a minute) You can build doors, floors, walls, bars, stairs, and light posts among other things. You can craft weapons, or repair ones you've broken, you can add modifications to said weapons too! Got a baseball bat, some nails, and a hammer? Create a spiked baseball bat that deals pretty significant damage and does it in style too. Barricading: This should probably go in the crafting section, but whatever. Barricading is something most of us zombie hunters have wanted to do for some time now, and sure some zombie games do have it, but Project Zomboid executes it brilliantly, the resources required for barricading are pretty rare depending on how lucky you are and what type of settings you selected before you started your game. (only in Sandbox mode can you select said options) You can barricade windows and doors, which not only helps keep the creeping zeds at bay, but also makes it so they can't see you through said windows, which is really cool. (you can also put sheets up to block outsiders from looking into your safehouse)Scavenging: This has been a part of modern zombie games for quite some time now, however this game does do one of the more realistic approches to it, food that you scavenge must be kept in a fridge or else it will spoil and make you sick if you attempt to eat it. Items that you need for crafting/barricading are pretty rare and thus valuable when found. You really need to pick and choose only the stuff you'll need at that moment when scavenging because you can only carry so much before becoming over encumbered, and don't forget you can always come back for whatever you can not bring with you at that time. There is another cool option about this, you can carry two bags with you at a time (this would require you to equip one bag in the secondary slot, and a big/normal, hiking/school bag equiped on your back) which gives you plenty of more space along with weight reductions applied from the bag(s) you have equiped at the time.Moodles: These are moodlets that pop up every now and then to tell you what your character is feeling/thinking, think The Sims, it's just like that. These can range anywhere from being tired, to getting cold, you'll want to keep a close eye on these. Most are not that important, however they're are some that do require your attention and you'll want to be on the lookout for such as, exhaustion, starving, getting sick, getting cold, getting wet, (when it rains) bleeding, and being in pain. A couple tips. 1) You'll want to avoid going out looting/killing during a storm because you'll get wet and will have an increased chance of becoming sick which could be the death of you if you don't take things easy. (killing zombies, running) 2) Lay down every now and then, you're not superman, your character needs sleep just as much as you do. 3) Make sure to always carry bandages/bandaids on you, in case you need to break open a window or patch up a wound, these are a necessity.Skills: This is a really fun feature in the game, you will develope skills according to how you play overtime. Do you like sneaking around avoiding the undead masses? Or do you like running in swinging hand over foot? either way will get you XP in these skills, which in time will unlock skill points that you can assign to your favorite most used abilities. Remember though, this is not carried over to multiple characters, if your character dies, all the abilities you've unlocked die with them.Farming: This is a pretty cool feature, it requires quite a few resources that may or may not be tricky to find depending on where you are and what options you've chose before starting the game. I'm not too experienced in this aspect as of the time of this review, however I do know that it is a great food source after the power/water has went out. You can grow your own crops inside your safe zone, or where ever, it really doesn't matter as long as you have the right materials you need, you can start your own little Farmville. (without being bombarded with 53,721 requests from people you barely know. I'm looking at you, Facebook)Distracting: You can distract the zombies with a few different methods, distracting a group of zombies could end up saving your life for another day. If you've got some gasoline handy and a few matches/lighter you could light up a near by house distracting the horde of undead while you easily sneak by and loot the otherwise damn near impossible house/building with ease. If you're playing with a friend(s) you can distract zombies while your friend goes in and loots the place dry by shouting at them, this will make your life a little bit harder though depending on how many of them there actually are, and Vice versa. Alams in houses can provide a quick distraction, if you're quick enough that is. Break a window or force it open in certain homes and you'll hear an alarm buzz for about 20-30 seconds, if you're quick enough to get out you can easily evade the on coming hordes making it easier to loot the outer area around the house you just sounded off, however this could very well be the end of your life if you get caught up in an oncoming group of zeds.Weapons: As with most zombie games, this game is based on melee/close quarter combat, there are guns available, however they're pretty rare, most are found in the cities and or gun stores, but of course those areas are hard to get to and loot without proper means, meaning you'll be doing most of your killing with a good ol' baseball bat/crowbar/golfclub, which is by no means a bad choice. (well except maybe the golfclub, you'd be better off fighting them with a toothbrush) The baseball bat has pretty decent durability, and is great against zombies, you can kill most zeds with a couple blows from a baseball bat, same with the crowbar, the better more rarer melee weapons such as the Axe and Sledgehammer are great too, however they're mostly located in the city areas, consider yourself lucky if you find one in the suburbs. Guns are great for clearing out areas, just make sure that you have enough ammo on you, because once you pull that trigger, it's on, that's like a dinnerbell to the infected.Be SMART: This game is heavily focused on realism, this isn't a game where you're an overpowered solider that cannot be killed, you can and probably will be killed quite a bit starting out. Only RUN when needed. Don't be a glutton and eat everything in sight, you may need that for another day. If you think it's a bad idea, then it is, and you shouldn't do it. And one last thing, STAY AWARE OF YOUR SURROUNDINGS AT ALL TIMES.Those are the main features of the game as of 4/20/2014 (Yea I know what day it is har har har)I'd like to add in that you will NEED to think before you act if you want to survive efficiently, this game is about your experience in the zombie apocalypse, what would you do in this situation if it actually happened? That's up to you, however, don't be careless, or else you will not survive for long.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								In short: The most massive and accurate zombie-apocalypse simulator that i know of, but rough around the edges and not quite finished.This game features a very diverse and rich pool of mechanics and allows you to play as you like to.You'll experience very intense situations but also quiet and boring periods, where nothing really happens, but the DEVs are working on NPCs (hopefully) which will stirr the whole mix up a bit (and you can play multiplayer if singleplayer is too calm for your taste).If you like role-play-games, sims and zombies, get it!Negative Stuff:-Fighting and movement feels disconnected, you don't get quite the feedback on visibility, hits and damage, etc. which is mostly because the animations and other visuals-related-stuff isn't done yet. Feels like you're not really in control, especially with movement and concealment, your character cannot lay down, hide or peek around corners.-Lack of real gameplay content; The game has a massive map with lots of great art and a huge number of zombies, but you can only survive and build/farm. After some time everything is settled and nothing substancial happens anymore. The DEVs are trying their best to address that but i don't see any fortune there without human NPCs. And just randomly sending hordes to your savehouse is stupid too, it seems fake and unfair.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								So I've gone through a few zombie games, the ones where you can update weapons like you are an engineer, where you can fight like a soldier, survive like Bear Grylls and are basically as inhumane and courageous as one of Daenerys' unsullied.  But I have always wanted to play a true zombie survival game and when I heard about Project Zomboid I decided to give it a go. Needless to say I died on my first day by stumbling in a hoard and thinking that with my flimsy butter knife I would kill them all. I died.. but I was excited. I realized that it's a different type of game, one where survival of the fittest is the phrase of the day. So like any excited person, after dying a few times I decided to check out youtube videos, improve and learn and then I gave it another go. It is an amazing game and I am proud to say I've survived 3 weeks already, I have an axe, a saw, lots of needles and a loooot of AMBITION. However, if you do decide to play this game just remember: "This is how you're going to die!"

content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Project Zomboid is one of the most unique zombie games ever made. It asks the question "In the zombie apocalypse, How will you survive, and what will be the cause of your demise?" This is a game that, if all its planned features are added, will rival other zombie survival horror games such as DayZ or 7 Days to Die. In the event you do not know the full extent of what they are looking to add, this includes an in depth survivor system that will allow you to join or start your own enclave of survivors, then supply them with the means to protect your new home. They also plan to add hostile NPC's because everyone knows in the event of the zombie apocalypse, their is nothing to stop a group of people from coming to your home and robbing everything you used to own, then shooting you and putting an end to your shortlived life in the Project Zomboid world. Did I mention that one day these muggers may not be NPC's, but entire bands of other players? No? Thats one of this games planned features as well.With all this being said, and there are still hundreds of more things to come, Project Zomboid is a game worth getting now, and a game worth the wait for later. I will recollect some of my expereinces to all who read this so you may furthur understand how this game is the zombie game we have all been waiting for.This story begins as it is my first time playing, my charactar is wearing a sweater and a little moodlet pops up on the side showing that it makes him a little warm, and so I swap the sweater with a vest and start to loot the rest of the house I had spawned in. After a long day of looting my charactar becomes hungry, thirsty and tired. After taking care of his Food and Water needs, I put him to bed. However in the middle of the night, two gunshots ring off close to the house, and while there are no NPC's yet, it still put me under the impression that someone was outside my house. The gunshots almost immediatly woke me up, and after waking up I heard a very distinct set of moans, and it is obvious to anyone that the gunshot drew a couple of the undead. However I did not grasp the danger of this situation until I stepped outside to a full on Horde. Only one of them noticed me as I bolted back inside and I hatched a plan. I would draw the horde in, then attempt to burn down the house. After coming up with this Idea I kept in mind this house had 6 exits, 4 including the windows around the house, and the 2 doors on opposite ends. I shoved a bunch of food and maybe some things not meant for the oven- into the oven, and turned it on. Over time electricity and plumbing turn off in this game but for now I was fortunate that it had not. After this I drew a large chunk of the horde into my home once the kitchen set ablaze. I didn't stop to see if it worked, I just simply ran on and on, putting as much distance between me and that horde as possible.I beleive that story to be best to show off how diverse the system of Project Zomboid is, with the appropriatly named "Sinister Ai" the game will generate random events such as house alarms for when you break into the window in an attempt to loot the place, or as you saw, random enviromental sounds such as jets, helicopters, gunshots and alarms that will draw or lead away hordes. Overall the pros of this game leave your screen and roll outside your house, yet the cons do as well. While this game is a great colaboration of everything any zombie fan has ever wanted in a zombie game, it still doesnt have ALL the features and it still is in Early Access, which means there will be a LOT of bugs, but if you can get past this you will get a game that will truly give you a fresh expereince every time.

Early Access Review
								THE Zombie Survival game.From one playthough, I can already see that Project Zomboid is just unforgiving, rewarding your impatience with a group of zombies pounding on the door of a closet that you desperately tried to hide yourself in whilst you crafted a molotov cocktail on the spot so you could burn down your entire house, taking as many zombies as you could with you.Seriously, though. If you happen to accidentally take a wrong turn or make a noise too loud, you can end up being bitten, and as soon as you're bitten, you genuinely die. Being bitten will actually progress into zombification (if that's the word). You've gotta choose your own safehouse, build your own defenses and scavenge for food yourself. The game does nothing for you except choose a spawn location. After that, the world is your metaphorical oyster!Just one violent, dark, flesh-eating oyster... Let's stick with that.

Early Access Review
								Let me start off this review by saying this; These game devs, are not like all the others. They care about their game, AND their community. They listen to what you have to say, and take it into great consideration. THAT BEING SAID; their update progress is slow. When they do update the game however, hardly anything is broken.The game as it stands, is very very enjoyable; with a great community. Gameplay can change at a moments notice, as you are sorting through your bag, a zombie could take a bite out of your neck, yikes! Project Zomboid makes you feel afraid. It doesn't hold your hand, it tells you "This is how you die.". And they're not wrong. You will die. Exploring buildings and looting can be great fun, as you get into tight situations with the undead. When you do manage to scratch out an existance in the game, it's a great feeling. Until the undead come crashing through your door...I'd rate this game right now at a 7.5/10Only because it's still in beta, or alpha or whatever. Updates are slow, but good when they release.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
Early Access Review
Project Zomboid Video Review! Project Zomboid-An isometric sandbox zombie survival game by The Indie Stone. In my humble opinion, one of the best survival games to date especially considering that there are a lot of zombie/survival games. I haven‚Äôt reviewed an early access title before, but, I wanted to do my part, however small, to help out The Indie Stone and make people aware of this amazing game, this studio has done amazing work despite all their troubles and I think that that‚Äôs really admirable, I won‚Äôt go into detail but, if you‚Äôre curious I would suggest researching on the net to find out more.  *PC*This game is only on PC. The options for the game are befitting of a PC, the game itself isn‚Äôt a major powerhouse so much older systems should have no problem running the game, and currently you can play with a controller (with split-screen co-op!) A very good PC game.  *PLOT*There is no story to speak of at the time of this review, there are however, plans to bring a story mode to the finished game, sandbox is all you‚Äôll find. You do however have a lot of options for your sandbox game, going so far as to decided how long the apocalypse has been going on for (with gameplay changes, more on that later),the game simply starts by putting you inside a house with the crazy world outside.  *STYLE*This game is isometric (top-down view) with art style that reminds me of Commands 2 Men of Courage, it‚Äôs got great detail and a very fitting look, I like this type of realistic style because, the proportions of the character to the world makes sense and, the world itself is very realistic with buildings and houses that look more modern. I do wish there were more style differences with clothes, weapons and zombies (especially as time goes on) but, what‚Äôs here is still pretty good (plus the game is mod-able) and there is always more being added. The music in this game can be very moody and fitting, this is my own personal taste but, I personally dislike the music with the parts of the middle eastern music (seems like a lot of zombie games have it strangely enough), it‚Äôs not that I dislike the genre in general, but, the game has this music that makes it feel very somber, sometimes peaceful, sometimes depressing, and it really gets me into the game, however, when that music starts in (and the women makes the ‚Äòchanting‚Äô noise) I get completely ripped out of it, it‚Äôs very jarring in my opinion, I think the game would be better with a focus on atmospheric music similar to that of Fallout or Wasteland 2 even, again it‚Äôs a personal preference of mine but, the style and feel of this game just doesn‚Äôt seem fitting with that type of music. Still a great style overall, I really enjoy isometric games as I feel you can get a lot more out of it visually and that especially works well with Project Zomboid.  *GAMEPLAY* Project Zomboid is perhaps one of the most realisticgames I have ever played and I don‚Äôt use that term often in association with video games. The game rewards you for very logical thinking, more so than in most video games (not to say video games need logic to be fun, but, referring to Payday 2, logically you shouldn‚Äôt be able to answer pagers period, much less four) as such this game is all about survival. Besides taking care of the basics, you‚Äôll need to keep your character healthy and sane, really the only thing missing is your characters don‚Äôt have to shower, or, go to the bathroom, everything else is pretty much there, the first aid system is pretty involved too, I climbed through a broken window, had to take out glass shards with tweezers, disinfect the cuts, and when the bandages got too bloody, had to replace them and clean the old ones. The other part of what adds to the realism is the length of time, you have great control over your settings of the world and can make it match up with the real world if you so wish, either way, in-game healing isn‚Äôt instant, if you break a bone you‚Äôre looking at a few weeks in-game before its healed, suffering from the negative affect all the while. Farming also takes months to yield any results, and that‚Äôs assuming your planets don‚Äôt get trampled by zombies or die of disease and you‚Äôre watering them regularly. As time progresses eventually, the running water and power that are available in the houses (or not depending on your options) will turn off, you‚Äôll need to plan ahead for these and if you don‚Äôt it‚Äôll be a slow painful death.  *COMBAT*Combat is pretty simple, you have your choice of melee weapons, guns and throwing weapons (like the classic Molotov-cocktail), you ready your weapon, point in a direction and swing/shoot. The longer you ready your weapon, the better the accuracy, and when zombies get close you can shove them away (some may even fall over) and either make a run for it or bash their brains in. Goes without saying that loud noises attracts more zombies and, fire spreads so be careful. You can also sneak past zombies. Combat does take its toll on your character, it‚Äôs enjoyable if simple, hopefully more weapons and toys are added to make going out with a bang more of a literal option.  *VERDICT*If you enjoy survival games or zombie games, you‚Äôll love this game, this is the most realistic game I‚Äôve played. Honestly, even if you don‚Äôt this is the type of game that is so good it might get you into a genre you‚Äôve never tried before. Its co-op and local split screen, so if you‚Äôve got a passive interest I highly encourage you to check it out, maybe get a friend to play with you, it can and is a lot of fun. And it‚Äôs priced at $14.99 USD and I see it on sale often, it‚Äôs well worth the asking price. Thank you The Indie Stone for an amazing game!  TL/DRA zombie survival game from The Indie Stone, they‚Äôve hit some rough patches, but, have still created one of the best survival games to date which is still only in early access. There is a ton of stuff planned for the future, but, what is here is a great game, it‚Äôs rewarding in all the right ways, makes you feel awesome for being smart and playing like a real survivalist. Its co-op and local split-screen, and the regular price is $14.99 USD which is a steal for this amazing game. If you‚Äôve ever had any interest I highly encourage you to take a hard look and really consider grabbing this game, it simply deserves to be played and I get excited for the day it finally sees a full release.  Thanks for the amazing experience  The Indie Stone!
‚ÄìTwo Thumbs Up from Royial
 Video Reviews @: The-RoyialNetwork

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								I will echo all the prior statements: The developers are slower than hell, the moderation (censor police) will scream or outright ban you out of their forums for any sort of criticism, and the severe ADD that has infected the feature-creep invested, broken promise loving, half baked feature giving team behind this game is second to none.To give you some perspective I was playing Rogue Survivor and Survival Crisis Z, not to mention flash games, in early 2011. Someone mentioned PZ to me and I backed them before their first demo was even out -- an outrageous idea at the time, but common now. What initially came to fruition was a polished and focused tech demo with a good art style, simple animations and aesthetic, and clunky but functional inventory system.I fired Build 34b up this week and I can say with assurance that almost nothing has changed. The art style has shifted to a pseudo-realistic stop motion, with a useless zoom feature and glitchy lighting. Running from house to house, room to room, fighting back awful controls and the exact same terrible inventory/looting system was a chore. The netcode is Direct Connect IP/Serverbox, with no dedicated servers or IP to IP hosting -- which makes no use of Steamworks.Combat is downright impossible with static repeating animations (or none at all) with each subsequent hit. Weapons break too frequently and are too rare, there are still no NPC's 5 years later. To close my review do not bother supporting Indie Stone, for I truly believe that high profile robbery that transpired years ago was the death of the "real" project zomboid. What we have now is an expensive tech demo.

content:

								A lamp is a replaceable component such as an incandescent light bulb, which is designed to produce light from electricity. These components usually have a base of ceramic, metal, glass or plastic, which makes an electrical connection in the socket of a light fixture. This connection may be made with a screw-thread base, two metal pins, two metal caps or a bayonet cap.

Early Access Review
								This game.. I don't really know where to start.Do note this is a very short and straight to the point review. When i got it.	The game was enjoyable, i loved the survivalness. The maps seem very well done. At this point i was enjoying the game and would recommend it. After a while	I started to notice the developers were very slow on there updates which i had no problem with. However after some time they kept repeating the same thing.Animations over and over. I thought they were done. But that's not the only thing. They don't seem to put out a lot of content. (And yes im aware the developer team is small. And like i said i understand for the slowness. )So then i decided i wanted to make a map and which i did it is called South Wuxburg or West Wuxburg. It was pretty good to me and people seem to enjoy it. Until one day.  Bugs and how they handle it. (mini rant)I have found many bugs and glitches with this game and it's getting very annoying. And yes im aware this is a EARLY access game but it's been out for over 2 years now. However it broke my workshop item once, And now there is a bug that has completely broken my world editor i use to edit my items. i reinstalled and everything..Before that i had another issue with the editor. I put in a report and got nothing and still nothing of the date of this review.I put that bug report in  October 3rd 2016, It's November 21st. No one has bothered to look it at or even message me about it. There was also a few other bug reports that are there. No one has responsed.I'm just showing how they don't seem to pay attection to bug reports. I Don't hate this game for this it's just very annoying and frustrating and the only way to get them to see this is to make a review. OVERALLGet this game if you like zombie survival games, You will enjoy the mutiplayer (if that don't bug out like it sometimes for me). This game is pretty enjoyable even at 66.4 hours. You can build, Fight, Barrcade and do a bunch of other stuff like crafting.  However be prepared for bugs and to know that the developers might not respond to your bug report. (for a while) Co-op can be extremely fun when the port forwarding works (and it's not my issue). There's lots of modifers to change out how you want the world to be. Make it easy, make it hard, Make it extremely hard. Customize your person. Use the workshop and download many cool mods and maps. Do note  i do not hate these developers and i love there game.	Also, i thought we were getting creative mode. It has gone slient in the blog posts they do. Other then that. Have fun playing this game if you do get it and hopefully this review has helped you.I am however not recommending this game since i am very tired of being forgottion and the bad support. Also Thanks for breaking the map editor.

content:
Posted: March 12
Early Access Review
Everyone saying this game sucks or is dying or will never get completed because we don't have NPCs/Vehicles/Animations yet will always find something to complain about. Those things will get implemented and then they'll be screaming something new.I don't even remember when I picked up this game, but I figured my love for it is pretty set-in-stone so a review couldn't hurt. I am a die-hard zombie fan, so hearing zombie survival on a scale like Zomboid instantly pulled me in. Everything the Devs are trying to bring keep me here more. This game is a gem, and it should be looked at as such.The gameplay is phenomenal, but remember this is just my opinion. The experience is heightened with headphones to really pull you in to the world, but without it still remains a tense and exciting environment. The subtle fade of the smooth atmospheric music which dynamically changes with your setting really helps, be it surrounded by deadly zeds and hearing frantic violins or on a roof cooking over a campfire to a soft piano. I've found myself so immersed in the setting many times that I have to mentally step back and remember I'm playing a game.March 11th, 2017The main issue with current development is highly anticipated features are taking extra time to roll out after being teased not too long ago. Vehicles are getting good, promising attention at current time of writing. No sight of NPCs yet, but animations seem two shakes away from completion. My thought is animations and vehicles will have release dates around each other if not the same time, but that is probably best-case scenario.Pros- Immersive, well-designed world with developing storyline and random finds- Early access, so a lot can still happen (which takes time)- Complex building/crafting/cooking systems -- Build your survival base, or fortify existing structures. New metalworking has been added for increased defensive structures. Count your calories to maintain a healty diet in a dying world. (:- Character specialization -- Be a chef, lumberjack, thief, or more! Varying attribute points are given to really tweak your character's performance.Neutrals- Clunky combat -- Anything other than melee is questionable to me with low skills, and even that sometimes gets odd. (*see footnote for expansion on this)- I personally don't find the UI to be a nuisance, but I can understand players disliking it.- Early access, so a lot can still happen (which takes time)- I'll keep this one neutral as it bounces back and forth, but things can get arduous fast. Fortifying can turn into luring a horde away from base. Luring a horde away can turn into getting lost/hurt/off track. Simple things like going to get some food downstairs and now you've got a shattered shin. You'll understand when you play.Cons- Early access, so a lot can still happen (which takes time, and has). This is what holds up a lot of people from enjoying what you have, and instead focusing on what you don't have. Early development is going to be a rollercoaster, and things will get halted for reasons that won't always get explained clearly if at all. You have to understand this if you wish to assist in early development. I believe in this title, and I believe it could grow to be a massively entertaining experience for a lot of people.- There is a slight lack-of-life to the world (no pun intended). No abandoned vehicles littering the roads, not much in the way of saying "there was an outbreak and panic ensued" other than TV or radio broadcasts during initial infection. Devs are working on introducing more world-clutter like this, but more important features take the front seat.I could write an even longer post and say so much more but you should really just experience it for yourself.(*In all my hours of playing, I haven't played with the guns too much other than shotguns and pistols. I have no clue how the aiming and reloading skills work at high skill levels because I've never gotten there myself.)March 28th, 2017Reading over some other helpful reviews and I was reminded how old this Early Access is. Correct, but you must remember that we are not playing the same exact version we used to play. They reworked the entire system a year or so ago. Hell, they even increased the resolution of textures. If the game isn't fun to you as-is, it won't be fun to you when the damned NPCs/Anims/Vehicles get added because you won't enjoy the CORE game.We've got active updates on two of the three long-awaited mechanics and people are still flailing about, damning Zomboid to development hell. Vehicles are being polished, and Animations are pretty much complete, what else do you want? You want it on a silver platter, immediately. Don't choose Early Access if you can't wait patiently.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Early Access Review:For a game that's premise is over-saturated, Project Zomboid stands unique and fresh compared to it's peers. Project Zomboid isn't your typical zombie game nor your typical survival horror game. Project Zomboid is more of a simulator than an RPG. When playing, you'll get frustrated so many times before actually getting the hang of everything as for PZ is a roguelike, once your survivor dies, he/she is dead forever. No matter how far your progress or big your fortress. Many of which mistakes you'll make is mostly because you got too over your head, or just plain stupidity. But once you get how the game goes, you'll surely live to see another day, maybe months.To fully enjoy the game, one must stop looking at this game as a survival RPG, and more of a survival sim. With the word simulator being said, this means managing, scheduling and farming. Think of it as a mash-up of The Sims + Farmville + Old-School Zombies. You gather supplies and build a base of operations where you can store your supplies and gear or maybe start a farm for food supplies. You can also choose to be a nomad and move from place to place.Moreover on being a simulator, you have to take care of your survivors needs, hunger, boredom and health should be taken care of and maintained well regularly. You can't just sit all day and wait. As you build your base, the game adds a Farmville + Tower Defense vibe to it. Make sure though you don't go gathering supplies at night as it gets pretty dark and dangerous. With this scheduling is also important, make sure you make a to-do list for the day, patience pays in this game, some areas are so infested that you have to postpone your scheduled scanveging trip. Everything is important in this game, make sure to gather everything for maybe in the future you may need it. For an Early Access Game, Project Zomboid is already filled with hours and hours of fun gameplay, as everything in the main gameplay is there, surviving, scavenging, building. It is announced and on paper though that NPC's will be added to give the game a more immersive feel and dynamic events. I personally am looking forward for the NPC's, imagine with the amount of different kinds of gameplay all mashed together in one added with NPC's and dynamic events all together can put this game into another way crazier level.I totally recommend this game for everyone, especially for people who are up for a challenge.

Early Access Review
								So... You think to yourself... Is this game REALLY worth buying? Do I really want to invest a rough $15.00 USD on this game? Well, lets start! This game places you into the middle of a zombie apocalypse... Literally, in the middle... You're heavily outnumbered...It 1 vs. 900,000+... Or something.Its survival too! Not bashing around, practically eating away at the zombie population, with a shotgun and infinite shells... in fact, shooting a shotgun will get you CHOMPED! This game has you making decisions, that are YOUR decisions. 'Do I go into the city to find better resources, or stay in the suburbs, living off meagre supplies?'.Choices like that, really.Zombies are also a threat, guys... Not the Mamby Pamby zombies we all know... ITS THE WALKING DEAD MATE! They wanna eat'cha! And'll break into buildings to do so! They also follow sound... so when you hear a helicopter come by, happily point that one middle finger at it and scream! Your death WILL come, there's no hope... this is how YOU died! Not survived! Heh, that would defy the whole purpose of the game! DYING!

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game is an excellent simulator for anybody who doesn't mind a bit of hardcore permadeath. If you die in this game, it's game over. No second chances, no revivals. Straight back to the main menu. The game does a very good job of handling the things you would feel in a zombie apocolypse. Stress, Lack of sleep, Pain, Panic, the full monty. It uses a rather unique "Moodles" system. It has different tiers of emotions that you go through, for instance anxiety, onto stress, onto extreme stress, onto terrified. The game has it's problems. For example they use both a number system and a moodles system and it gets confusing. I don't mind the moodles system, in fact I admire the originality but I would say make the number stats system visible too.On the whole I really appreciate the game, it has brilliant developers, posting the oh-so amazing mondoids and with a sense of humor anyone'd die for.  Keep up the good work, dev team if you're reading this, and if you're thinking of buying the game, I say go for it as long as you don't mind a bit of hardcore. It has LOADS to do to keep you busy and theres constantly new features as well as the option to go back to the previous build. The price is great too, it's nice and compact and the animation is pretty darn good. Thanks for reading, Ickleslimer.
