content:
Posted: November 10, 2013
Early Access Review
								Definitely one of the best Zombie games that i have ever played. It was also one of the first Indie games that I ever purchased. The game challenges you to survive for as long as possible, At first, the world is very similar to how it would be without zombies, only they are roaming outside. But as you survive, the electricity shuts off, lights no longer work. You must roam with a flashlight to cut through the dark Mudlraugh wilderness. Then the water shuts off, you must collect water bottles, pop bottles. Or construct a barrel to store some rain water. All while evading hordes of zombies, and risking infection in all of your close quarter battles. You are a regular survivor, every scratch and bite has a chance to turn you into a moaning, bloody mess. Sometimes a frying pan isnt enough to save you when zombies are breaking in through every entrance of your shelter. The game is definitely worth the $15, as i have far more hours on it than almost any commercial game if you count desura time, and the moaning of zombies is calling you to fight or die. However, a warning, when you get insanely addicted to this, and want more zombies, you will be disappointed by the other games. Visuals - 9 for what its meant to be and an IndieSound/Music - 10, scary moaning and awesome soundtrackStory - Not back in place (maybe never it seems) Gameplay - 10EDIT: While most of my review from Nov 2013 stands true, since then the indiestone team have implemented a full world decay system so buildings/roads Crack and break or grow over with grass and bushes (originally by a modder that joined the devs), implemented seasonal tiles (now there's snow!),  have redone the whole game in double resolution for when you zoom in, added a bit of the world meta events,  and added a great multi-player mode and expanded the map with a major expansion. However, game is still lacking the most requested feature of NPCS, and I feel underestimated the difficulty of adding such complex AI interaction. However, that is supposedly there current focus but if that's a deal breaker for you it's still not in...Basically, If you can handle the isometric view this is probably the best zombie survival game that you will find and it does go on small sales  periodically.  This is what started my addiction to Early Access/Indie games.EDIT: 3 Years later and they're still talking about adding NPCs but all we've really seen is their brain storming chart for interactions. Kind of sad this and Kenshi were one of the first Indies I ever got and 5 years later it's halted development. Honestly I don't think developers do anything anymore and it's just the modder they hired on carrying the project. Still a great game and I recommend it but it's jsut sad to see them working on easier stuff the community doesn't ask for because they don't want to release the challenging stuff like a story or NPC characters. I understand before they wanted it to be perfect but when Kenshi (a solo dev until the last year) is faster than a team, we got problems...Basically its still an amazing survival game and really is one of the best zombie survival games. If you've ever watched zombie shows or movies and been like hm I wonder what I would do, buy this game for sure. But don't buy it for future content of vehicles or NPCs, buy it for once in it now. Still one of my favorite indies. Kenshi is very different but an amazing indie that's come so so far. Subterrain is another survival game that is great if you like Doom atmosphere.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
Early Access Review
								Project Zomboid is Day Z meets Minecraft in a 2D isometric world. Still in alpha, but with plenty of game play to keep players entertained for hours, Project Zomboid drops you in the middle of a suburban landscape as the sole (in the current build at least) survivor of a classic zombie outbreak. You will die, this is inevitable. The question (and objective) the game poses is: how long will you survive? Surviving isn't as simple as staying indoors and out of sight however. Like a normal person you have needs. Hunger, thirst, sleep, and entertainment are periodic needs that must be fulfilled lest you risk your health and sanity. Satisfying these needs will require venturing outside and scavenging for supplies. At first it all seems so simple: find some food to eat, maybe some magazines to read and you're all set, water's still coming out of the tap after all and as long as the window shades are closed no zombie will come looking for you, that is until one follows you home and starts pounding on the window. "Maybe he'll just go away" you think, but before you can act the window is broken and the zombie is inside. Run or fight, those are your options. You've spent too long gathering supplies to run and you're too tired to get very far so you're going to have to fight, but with what? Quick! To the counter! The kitchen knife. You grab the knife just in time and violently stab the intruder over and over before finally it succumbs.Maybe the house isn't as secure as you thought and now the window is broken. Perhaps if you had a hammer, some boards, and nails you could barricade it up. If you're going to head out to find these things however you'll need a better weapon and you'll have to find that too. Maybe surviving isn't going to be so easy afterall.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
Early Access Review
								(As of this writing, the game is still in its alpha stage)Whereas most survival horror games lack very much in the former and deliver light on the latter, Zomboid is actually a pleasant surprise. I got burned out on zombies around the release of Left 4 Dead 2 and Dead Rising, but Project Zomboid brings much more to the table. This is a game that stresses survival, and over time renders many of your sources of living (heat and water) inoperable, forcing you to scavenge for food and water. Zombies are few and far between in rural areas, but fire off one shot from a pistol, and you might as well just start over again as a horde from yards away begins shuffling their way towards you. The carpentry and farming features, though limited a bit in the alpha at this time, are still deep and intuitive enough to provide you the means of survival. However, as the tagline states, it's not a matter of IF you die, but when. Play it smart, and you'll make a tidy little utopia for yourself in the zombie infested wastes of Kentucky. Play it dumb, and expect about half the town of Tuscaloosa to turn your‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•into a human buffet.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
Early Access Review
								I have re-written my review, as i last wrote it in 2013 having played 20 hours.  I'm now up to 80+ hours and the year is 2015, a lot can change in that space of time...There is only one real negative to this game and that is the multiplayer, or rather trying to play with your friends.  It's easy enough to just join a server and play online, obviously if all your group join the same server you can play together; however, the problem comes when you want to set up a private game with your own rules.  It is not easy to do (I could just be being a bit of an idiot though, feel free to leave comments if you know of a better way than what I came up with) and in the end my group had to use Hamachi to create an online LAN.  By far and away the biggest positive has to be the developers, they up date this game so much! When I started playing there where only a handful of skills (blade, blunt, lightfooted, sprinting, cooking, carpentry, sneaking) now there are at least double that number.  Same goes for occupations (think character classes), when I began there were only 4 or 5.The game is really challenging, mistakes are punished; I would compare it to dark souls in its difficulty, in that if you die you can attribute it to a mistake you have made.  Crafting/survival mechanics are great, build a house, trap animals, fish, farm, explore and scavenge.  Stay out in the rain too long, get wet, get cold, get ill and die.  Don't prepare well enough for the power and water to shut off - starve and die of thirst.  Climb through a broken window without removing the glass, maybe you will be fine, maybe you will cut yourself, maybe that cut will get infected because you have no medical kit. Walk into the wrong part of town, get surrounded, get eaten.  Or lose all hope, drink a bottle of bleach and kill yourself!Combat is very simplistic, which helps create tension when fighting off hordes.  Time attacks well and zombies go down easy.  Mess it up and it is easy to get overwhelmed.  Mods galore, this game is early access but it has more workshop content than most!One final negative, there is no real story to the game yet, hopefully it is going to arrive relatively soon, so late game can end up getting a bit stale.  The journey to that point is absolutely fantastic though.Without a doubt, the most value for money I have ever gotten from a computer game... Ever.Big shout out to the developers for doing such a good job.  Guys like you are why early access was created and it is a pity more developers don't work to your high standards.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
Early Access Review
								Project Zomboid is Day Z meets Minecraft in a 2D isometric world. Still in alpha, but with plenty of game play to keep players entertained for hours, Project Zomboid drops you in the middle of a suburban landscape as the sole (in the current build at least) survivor of a classic zombie outbreak. You will die, this is inevitable. The question (and objective) the game poses is: how long will you survive? Surviving isn't as simple as staying indoors and out of sight however. Like a normal person you have needs. Hunger, thirst, sleep, and entertainment are periodic needs that must be fulfilled lest you risk your health and sanity. Satisfying these needs will require venturing outside and scavenging for supplies. At first it all seems so simple: find some food to eat, maybe some magazines to read and you're all set, water's still coming out of the tap after all and as long as the window shades are closed no zombie will come looking for you, that is until one follows you home and starts pounding on the window. "Maybe he'll just go away" you think, but before you can act the window is broken and the zombie is inside. Run or fight, those are your options. You've spent too long gathering supplies to run and you're too tired to get very far so you're going to have to fight, but with what? Quick! To the counter! The kitchen knife. You grab the knife just in time and violently stab the intruder over and over before finally it succumbs.Maybe the house isn't as secure as you thought and now the window is broken. Perhaps if you had a hammer, some boards, and nails you could barricade it up. If you're going to head out to find these things however you'll need a better weapon and you'll have to find that too. Maybe surviving isn't going to be so easy afterall.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								I would say if you want to get more of a single player experience with a zombie survival game then this is the game you want to get. There are a multitude of ways to customise your game before you play. From the type of game, time, character settings, traits, zombie movement and amount etc. Never one game will be the same. With the addition of multiplayer in the future and a lot of planned features you can see on the store page, this is definitely a great purchase.As to how this game plays, it is not a walk in the park. This game is true survival at heart and you can't be complacent and the more risks you take, the more likely you are to die. Some ways I have died have been from not clearing a house before looting, getting cornered by a horde inside a house and also outside, eating rotten vegetable, getting sick from being out in the rain too much, falling off the stairs (early beta), not making sure a zombie on the ground is dead, walking through a forest and then suddenly getting set on by a horde, leaving the lights on or window open for visibility, getting shot by an npc (early beta), attacking a zombie on the road only to attact more further down it, burning the house down by leaving the oven on. Longest I've lived for was 10 days. I'm still new to this game and have heard about the farming, building and crafting available to build defences and to hold out against a moving zombie horde. Great game and definitely would recommend it to friends.Looting houses, hospitals, churches, markets, shopping centres, schools, sheds, cabbins, apartments, restaurants, gp centre, warehouses, commercial buildings what more can you ask for?

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
Early Access Review
								I have re-written my review, as i last wrote it in 2013 having played 20 hours.  I'm now up to 80+ hours and the year is 2015, a lot can change in that space of time...There is only one real negative to this game and that is the multiplayer, or rather trying to play with your friends.  It's easy enough to just join a server and play online, obviously if all your group join the same server you can play together; however, the problem comes when you want to set up a private game with your own rules.  It is not easy to do (I could just be being a bit of an idiot though, feel free to leave comments if you know of a better way than what I came up with) and in the end my group had to use Hamachi to create an online LAN.  By far and away the biggest positive has to be the developers, they up date this game so much! When I started playing there where only a handful of skills (blade, blunt, lightfooted, sprinting, cooking, carpentry, sneaking) now there are at least double that number.  Same goes for occupations (think character classes), when I began there were only 4 or 5.The game is really challenging, mistakes are punished; I would compare it to dark souls in its difficulty, in that if you die you can attribute it to a mistake you have made.  Crafting/survival mechanics are great, build a house, trap animals, fish, farm, explore and scavenge.  Stay out in the rain too long, get wet, get cold, get ill and die.  Don't prepare well enough for the power and water to shut off - starve and die of thirst.  Climb through a broken window without removing the glass, maybe you will be fine, maybe you will cut yourself, maybe that cut will get infected because you have no medical kit. Walk into the wrong part of town, get surrounded, get eaten.  Or lose all hope, drink a bottle of bleach and kill yourself!Combat is very simplistic, which helps create tension when fighting off hordes.  Time attacks well and zombies go down easy.  Mess it up and it is easy to get overwhelmed.  Mods galore, this game is early access but it has more workshop content than most!One final negative, there is no real story to the game yet, hopefully it is going to arrive relatively soon, so late game can end up getting a bit stale.  The journey to that point is absolutely fantastic though.Without a doubt, the most value for money I have ever gotten from a computer game... Ever.Big shout out to the developers for doing such a good job.  Guys like you are why early access was created and it is a pity more developers don't work to your high standards.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
Early Access Review
								Project Zomboid is about how long you will survive in a zombie apocalypse. You will die eventually. This game doesn't hold your hand much, you need to find your way around in a ruthless environment where zombies are not your only enemies.This game has all the elements I've been waiting to see in a zombie survival game. Crafting, cooking, building and farming. All this while scavenging stuff out there and slaying zombies. It's best to try to avoid them zombies though, you might catch the virus yourself or get surrounded if you are not careful.I see huge potential in this game, when they will add NPC's and online multiplayer this game will be absolutely brilliant. At the moment there are some bugs, weird design choices and awkward usability, but I'm sure they will be ironed out in time.This is THE zombie apocalypse game you want.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you're looking for an authentic "zombie survival" experience, then look no further.No other zombie survival game that I have played (and I have played many) imbues the same level of depth and emotion as this game does. Threats are all around you, and you will not survive, but the real question is how far will you make it? Thirst,  hunger, sleep deprivation, heat, cold, depression, boredom, sickness, infection, and of course: Zombies. The choices you make will determine how long you will  last, leading to some difficult decision making. The game does a fantastic job of portraying a zombie apocalypse in all it's horror and darkness.  The zombies are "proper" zombies. That being, slow, shambling, and non-superhuman undead as portrayed in Max Brook's "Zombie Survival Guide" and "World War Z" (The BOOK not the movie!). The threat of infection is real. One scratch is all it takes unless you're lucky. And if you've been bitten, it's game over no matter how much you try and fight it; what's left is how you choose to spend the last few days of you're life. It'll make you think twice before courageously taking on a small horde of zombies with your baseball bat. Simply by playing the game, you are creating your own story for your character. It's a dynamic world full of zombies and you get to decide what you want to do and what your priorities are. There is lengthy character progression through a skill system, making you're character all the more precious as you invest more time into them. The longer you're alive, the more you'll want to survive. The game is still in Alpha, so it's considered incomplete by the developers, meaning there are many more features to come. I can't wait to see what they add to this game as time goes on. It already feels like a complete experience, so anything new they put in can only add to it. This game is worth every penny. Something that I have a lot of difficulty saying about many other games.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Project Zomboid has come a long way. The development staff has weekly updates to let you know what will be released and what is on the agenda. The gameplay is smooth and fun. This is a survival game at it's best. An immersive medical system and cooking system. Combat is being worked on to contain more moves and animations so it does feel a bit dull right now. The graphics are a top down, isometric look. Your character is customizable down to the skills they possess. As you play the game, your skills will level up and you can add points to certain skills, blunt and accuracy are an example of them under the melee skills. You will die eventually either due to carelessness or unproper planning. The game time can extends to days as your in game time spans years. With the new updates you can watch the world around you deteriorate. Radio broadcasts and in game events will keep you aware of how society is devolving.Please buy this game and support these devs if these things interest you. In comparison to other games alpha releases this game ALONE stands the test of time with constant updates and dev to community transparency. This game WILL be updated and WILL become better. It already has a ton of content and will have more in the future from NPCs to new items in game, including cars. 10/10 would survive again for a year and die in the winter due to crop failure in my huge built up fortress

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
Early Access Review
								Reviewing at Alpha Stage: I took a quick look at the pictures and one video, noticed a demo was shared to us the consumer I decided to give it a shot.Demo: The demo starts you off as a female hidden away, you're bitten which allows you to play for a couple of days before becoming a zombie, this is a tipical demo feature which stops you from playing the game for free and thinking that is all it. The demo gave me a strong impression on what it is capable of so I decided to buy it for a low cost compared to other indie games.The Alpha: Bugs, glitches, crashes will happen in every single alpha so I tend to ignore these a little whiles doing a review unless it is a major issue which it is not and I am happy to continue this review.The main menu is brilliant, the lightning flashes with the music kicking in that reveals a hidden dark secret to the two characters on screen, you have three game modes Survival, Last Stand, Sandbox.  Survival; As the game is meant to be, you create your character with its pros and cons, you start in  one out of two worlds which random generates items and your starting area which opens your eyes up and scares you from roaming too far in the early stage, you need to keep fed, watered, fit and infection free! If you're a zombie fan then playing this is logical, play it as a movie and real life scenerios for survival and you will not have a problem on keeping alive....until you meet zombies, they are slow, fast, weak and strong...some walk, some run, some crawls, they're all attracted to smell of blood dripping, sound and sight which creates or breaks hordes up.Sandbox; just like survival but you're in control for a while on what the world can be like for zombies, make them weak or super hard.Laststand: You're holding out aslong as you can before death, there is only one way to win.... stand and defend as long as you can.....Winning is death in my eyes.Graphics might look weak to you but they really fit the game well, sounds are brilliant from zombie growls, sounds of guns, alarms, windows smasing, doors breaking and more.For an Alpha it is well done for its pre-release, if you can not hack bugs, crashes, glitches then wait until people report less and less.6.6 rating for alpha. I will review it once again when the game has improved to be held by its title on its own which will be on my site.   YES I will recommend it to my friends. (Playing it on a IMAC OSX Snow Leapod.)

content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								I bought this Game before it wa Ever a Steam Game, 1.5d Alpha Build with Kate and Baldspot, If there is an Early Access Game that Derserves Every Cent. Then its this one. The Game Is about how you die. How you live you're Last days on earth Surviving the Zombie Apocaplyse. Hunger, Thirst, Even the Weather is Agaisnt you. You Adapt, or Die. Simple as that. You cant Win. You Cant Cure this Virus. Humanity is Dwidling into Extintion. So what are your final days going to hold?Ive played this Game for 300+ hours Including the Time I played it on Dersura and in Early Builds. Pros -Total Customization - You want Walking Dead Zombies, You got them. YOu want Super Human 28 Days Later Infected. You got them. Its all Customizable in Sandbox ModeIts Challenging - This Game will Tear you a new one. Litterally. Zeds Grab, Bite, Scratch and You best Believe Gun Shots Bring on Hordes. Houses can Have Locked Doors/Window. Have House Alarms. Lastly The Medical/First Aid Is Ace. Oh you jumped out a Window to Escape Zeds? Have fun Running with a Broken Leg. Splints, Sewing Wounds Shut. Disinfecting them so they dont get Infected.(Does not get rid of "Zombie" Infections). Only Infections on WoundsPlay How You Want - You can play However you want. There will be Consequences for some styles of Play. But All In all the Game can Be Played How you want. You can go around guns blazing, or take everything stealthyMap Size -  The Map isnt something that you can jog acrossed in no time. It can take a few days in Game to move from one Town to Another. Right now These Towns are Muldraugh and West Point. But the Modding Communtiy has add New Denver, Bedwood Falls, Dreadwood, The Walking Dead Prison and The game will soon have a Creative Mode so you can Create your own Cities/TownsCons - Some Features have Been In Development For a long time. NPC's have been In Development for the Good part of 2 Years, Dont Be Dicouraged though. They Want to Make Sure Everything Works and Is Balanced and Stable within the World Of PZ. (You can Go to their Forums and Find loads of Information of the things they are currently Working on)

content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								A lot of zombie games share a common flaw. Zombies serve only as target practice. The aspect of prolonged survival in a post apocalyptic world is pretty much ignored, other than the occassional reference or scene. The concept of rebuilding in this new world is also forgotten. You just go from point A to B and shoot some zombies, that's it. And then there's Project Zomboid. You get to shoot zombies (bad idea!), but you also get the chance to rebuild. Find a good spot, build a wall and before you know it, you've got your own base to defend.Of course, it's not that easy, but it should give a good idea. The game has carpentry, farming and most recently even hunting was added (to an extent). Which brings me to the second point. The company constantly adds more content. It's a good habit, one I hope to keep seeing for a long time.So I definitely recommend this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								Project Zomboid is pretty much your typical zombie survival game.First of all, any fans of being a Bandit in Dayz. This game is not for you.Now that's out of the way Project Zombiod is a 2D zombie survival game. Its simple you wake up in a house in a large town split into two districts. You search around the houses cupboards, draws and even the fridge for supply's. Now you go to the window and see that their are many other house's around you probabaly containing even more loot. You open your front door and look out and see no sigh of trouble. You walk over to the house and find that the front door is locked. You walk around the side and open the window. You enter the house and start to look around. You manage to find yourself a new crowbar to use as a weapon. You also use a plastic bag to help you hold more food. You walk up the stairs and see a Zombie jump out at you. You beat it to death but notice that your character is now worried and frightened. You walk back to your house but as you open the front door a zombie sneaks up from behind and attacks you. You spin around, pull out your crowbar and beat it to death. You walk inside than treat yourself to a nice cold TV Dinner. 15 minutes later you get sick and die. Because you didnt cook the food.That was my first 20 Minutes in project zomboid and it made an impression. Sure its a simple survival zombie game but its felt real. The scaverging is where the games best moments are. Breaking into houses and carfully moving from room to room, collecting bed sheets to put on the windows as curtains back home so Zombies arn't attracted to the light. The game plays like any basic 2D game. Just move and click. You have two menus which display your inventory and whats around you. It is very basic in that way. But its how your character is and feels that works well. If you get attacked by a zombie your player will become panicked and won't be as accurate with his hits. Or if your at your base waiting around or reading about new skills your chacter will become bored which can lead to the charcter being un-happy. The weapons are basic. You just swing your bat in the direction and the target and it will hit it. Or if you have a gun its pre much auto-lock. No skill is required you just look,shoot and you hit your target. Their are no cars in the game so your always walking which can become repative and boring. The game is fair from realistc but feels real in a way that you always find stuff in places where you would expect stuff to be. Unlike in Dayz where you find stuff lying on the floor. Here you look in draws,shelfs and fridges to find loot. I love entering new houses or areas not knowing what is going to be there.The game isn't extremly easy. If you find yourself in a horde of zombies, to put it nicely. You're ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ed. Zombies are a threat even though they can be taken down by one shot at times with a gun, zombies will hear this shot and close in on you. Once me and my friend were trying to loot a bank, we ran into the parking lot to find a horde of zombies waiting for us. We panicked smashed the window and jumped inside. I lost sight of my friend as 4 zombies that were already in the building closed in on me. I freaked out, pulled out my pistol and shot all 4. Worst decison of my life. Now zombies were flodding in, smashing windows  and breaking down the door's. As I had now discoverd my friend had left me for dead. I ran upstairs and tried to find a new way out and had no luck. As I tried to open a window to see if I could climb out. Zombies snuck up behind me and started attacking me. Already injuired I was dead in seconds. The game isn't easy seeing that zombies are easily attracted to noise and you can only see a small distance where your chacter is facing. The game can be hard on your own. But play it right or with friends and you will grasp it.Now eventually you will find yourself sellting down and buliding a base. Base building consits of two things, Physical Bulding and Farming. You can build walls to fortify your house and make a large farming area that you have to fertilise and water. It's basic but it works. Farming is also a great idea because eventually all water and power supply stops. So you cant keep your food in the fridge or drink water from the tap. Once you have a base I can find the game can begin to get repatative and boring. Eventually I found myself repeating the same thing. Going out and scaving as much as I can than bring it home. With the occasional farm. That is where the game really lacks. It get's boring. Their's no big multipalyer too. Sure you can join  populated severs but its just a cluster-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. In the single player theirs no AI, no objectives, no events or anything like that. I wish their was the occasional moment when you run into a gang of AI and have a all out war. Or find other bases to break into or raid. Or maybe make a town and have AI work in it. All this can be added and I wish it will. Im sure AI will be added at some point with other features because right now after a while the game gets boring. But that is a matter of hours in. You can always start a new life fresh on your own or with friends and do it all again.The music in the game is great I have to say.THE VERDICT:Pros:-Zombie AI works great-Scavaging is fun- Looks fresh and new-Good fun with friends-Feels real but not too real-Base buildingCons:-Not a whole lot to it-Gets repeative after a while-No AI makes the only threat zombies-Big severs don't workRATING: 8/10The game is worth the price by a mile. I know the game is in early acceses so they will add new things and the game will get even better and the score would probably be bosted up to and 8 or maybe even a 9. But for now it's diffently worth it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 10, 2013
Early Access Review
								So... I had a previous review when I'd played for about 30 hours that made zero sense, as I'm fairly certain that I had created the review in a drunken stupor... So, now that I've had a couple (500 or so) hours of playtime since then, I figure I would update my review...Project Zomboid is exactly what it advertises itself to be- it is a zombie survival game which you will not survive. It even goes so far as to tell you that when you start the game (i.e. "this is how you died") Permadeath adds a lot to equasion, especially after having spent 10 hours building a base, only to get your face bitten off by a zed while running about trying to get find a pizza. That may not be somthing many people are looking for, but for those of us who are willing to try, try again- the next time you'll last 15 hours and have a bigger base before you get your face bitten off by a zombie while looking for a pizza.Now, for all my hours of gameplay I have only played multiplayer for about 4 or 5 hours, and during that time- not once did I meet another player... and I'm okay with that. Multiplayer games just mean I have to deal with ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s that will suck the fun out of everything and cause me to have to search for items over and over again as they get stolen from me. Not my cup of tea.There have been multiple reviews which have critisized the developers for taking quite some time in the development of the game, addition of new features etc, and lament the fact that the game is still in early access...Personally, having played the game on both Steam OS and Windows, I'd say that the game has come a hell of a long way since the original "Kate and Bald Spot" story that introduced me to this gameplay. (Give her a pillow! It's fun!)The developers are (perhaps a bit slowly) adding more and more layers to the game, and each patch brings great improvements not only adding additional gameplay options, but improving both the look and the "feel" of the game. They do an excellent job of informing people of what they are working on and how it is coming along... so my best guess is that people who think the developers are completely stagnating are illiterate idiots, and quite possibly blind. But I don't actively involve myself in the community- so what do I know.I've seen a lot of early access games that get dumped by the developers before making them remotely playable, let alone enjoyable...So- I would say, if the price was over 20 dollars- I'd say wait till it came on sale or was a bit further in development. But for 15 bucks- it's worth it. Every penny, any day. From the sound, to the feel, to the developers keeping they players informed and involved... It's a generally damn good game.Have a nice death :-)

content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is the zombie survival experience I've been waiting for for a long time. While it consists of typical zombie survival fare such as looting houses and shops for weapons and supplies, fighting off hordes of zombies and barricading windows and doors, it offers many more unique facets of gameplay that set it apart from other games of the genre. There truly is so much packed into this game, such as the "moodlets" which indicate current emotional, mental and physical state, not unalike the something from the Sims, or details as simple yet intuitive as hanging up bedsheets above uncurtained windows so as to break the line of sight of zombies, who would otherwise attempt (and succeed) in breaking in and murdering you. Foods rot without refridgeration, but then utilities such as water and electricity will cut off eventually, forcing you to stock up on non-perishables like canned soup or farming your own, and rain collecting barrels must be built. You can add an additional level to your house for a greater field of view and to reinforce your defenses. If you find even these features lacking, there is already a vibrant selection of mods to add even more to already rich game. The best part is that this is only just the beginning for this game. There are so many features to come, such as local and online multiplayer, NPC's and animals (and therefore hunting as well) and I can only see a bright future for it. Yet despite it's the fact that it is still in an early stage of development, it is already enormously playable.I strongly urge you to buy this game if you have an interest in the zombie survival genre, and I would like to remind you that every dollar aids the developers in it's creation.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								For the 90 hours that I've put into this game (Singleplayer Survival Only), I can tell you that this game has a lot, A LOT, of potential. Of course, this game is all about survival, no happy ending, no cure, no nothing, and this is a concept that a lot of Zombie Survival Game out there forgot. Survivalism isn't that threatening in those other games, but in Project Zomboid, things are different. I mean, as soon as you create a game, you can clearly read "This is how you died".Of course, some people might say that there is no point at all, no goals, no "missions", etc. This is not entirely true, as the point of the game is to create your own stories after all. How will you die? This question as yet to have been answered by you! Also, when I said that this game has a lot of potential, I was referencing to the future features that it has to offer (it's in Early Access for a reason). To begin with, NPCs (not yet implemented) will have a huge impact on the gameplay, since they will become a huge part in each playthrough. Plus, NPCs will be able to give more goals to the player, as he will be able to interact with them in many different ways. To sum up, Project Zomboid might be in Early Access for a while, but it will definitely be worth it. From building a community for all survivors to putting them out of their misery when they get bitten by a zombie, Project Zomboid is one of the best, if not the best Zombie Survival Game of all time!

Eh, just an idea. Keep up the fantastic work!

								What a fantastic game.  This is kind of like the Sims (original version) meets DayZ.  If you love open world, exploration, crafting with survival horror thrown in then I would highly recommed you check this game out.  On the demo version you can get 1hr play time before you will die because you start with an infection.  Full retail game has more game modes, save and save on crash. The thought and design that has gone into this game is excellent.  I am really enjoing this game and it is still early access.  So much more to come such as NPCs, story mode, Multiplayer servers and more.  I highly recommend PZ. content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've wanted this game since 2011, I saw Dopefish play it and I thought it was real fun, I tried buying it but it was not on Steam or any other trusted platform. The've come a long way from 2011, the game looks MUCH better and polished, and it's not even done.* You can pretty much turn the game to whatever you like, if you like classic dumb zombies you can do that, or superhuman fast zombies.* Don't let the looks fool you, you can farm and build in this game. Medical attention is very fun since it's not just "drink soda or eat something to restore hp", It actually focuses on the parts of the body that are damaged and require tools to attend to your wounds. *Skills are good, but I feel like it's kinda tedious how the XP system works at the moment (just an opinion). *The map is HUGE. and there's custom maps. I'm really excited for vehicles cause It's pretty tedious to just run whenever you want to go, and you have to travel several days to other spots of the map. *The map actually degrades overtime. Trash accumulates, windows break, walls crack, vines grow over walls and windows, grass starts to grow around the concrete, it's very nice. *Multiplayer is fun but it's better to play with friends if you don't play on a daily basis.*NPCs were removed but they are working on them again, so you won't be alone when surviving.Overall it's a pretty fun game so far, a couple little bugs and a couple things I'd love they implemented but it's still under development. Devs are cool, they give you every monday a blog post about what are they working on and the news about the next build. It's very much worth the 15 dollars.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is the best zombie survival game I've played, and I've played a few. The devs are great, giving the community large, game-enhancing updates at regular intervals, as well as a newsletter on their progress every Monday. Every time I come back to this game after a new update, I feel as if I'm hooked on the game all over again, simply because it's more immersive than ever. Also, it's surprisingly difficult to survive, at least for long periods of time. Custom sandbox is great for toning down the number of zombies and their ferocity, giving you a chance to get to grips with the game (there is also a beginner mode for those who don't want to fiddle around with settings), and survival mode is just brutal - lots of zombies, hardly anything to scavenge, so don't expect to last long. There's nothing like being bitten and fending off a horde of bloodthirsty zeds, knowing that you're not going to survive anyway, so you might as well go out on a high. :PNPC's is a feature that I'm really looking forward to that is yet to be implemented, but I hear they are working on it. They've recently added radios, TV's and walkie-talkies with Build 33 which may be an interesting development in later updates, such as being able to talk with NPC's over the ham radio; also good for multiplayer too, as bases can keep in contact with the people they send out to scavenge.Overall an excellent game with active devs that looks as if it's going to get even better. Would totally recommend for fans of zombie and/or survival games, as well as anyone looking for a nerve-wracking experience which will have you hiding in your house, clutching a baseball bat, as the zeds come knocking on the windows! Have fun!

Early Access Review
								Great game on the surface. But as you play it only continues to impress and surprise you with incredibly in depth "crafting" (I use this term lightly, because its more of a "turn this thig into that" kind of thing), and game mechanics. The game offers an innovative new addition to zombie-survival games, with the field of view mechanics; as zombies leave your field of vision they fade from view, and do not reappear until you see them again, or are close enough to be heard. A great buy, can't wait to see how far the devs take the game!

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Extremely impressive in terms of interactivity, think even Ultima 6/7 didnt have that much stuff you could do with stuff and stuff and also what stuff could do to you. Im really abit at a loss at what to list as an example. Of course theres cooking with an extensive array of utensils and ingredients. You could drink a bottle of whiskey to get abit happier. Then you could fill that bottle with water to have something to drink when theres no toilet (yup) or sink near. Then you could put that bottle into a plastic bag you found for abit of weight reduction, but then you of course could use only one handed weapons, better to have a backpack. Then when you get hungry you could pour that water into a bowl and if you had flour you could make dough, if you had ramen you put that together and then put it into any near oven. If you dont want the zombos to disturb you you could hang some sheets on the windows and switch of the light, and read a magazine to reduce some boredom while you wait until its done. And theres lots of other interactions like that.Combat is simple but functional, as are the graphics (abit of Postal 1 and Jagged Alliance) and controls. Inventory management/looting seems complicated at first but its really not if you get a hang of the menues.It really seems like a waste that this great framework of interactivity is wasted on yet another "fart around until you die" sandbox instead of being the basis for at least an rpg-lite with at least a few rudimentary goals. But seeing as its exactly advertised as a "fart around until you die" sandbox it delivers, and boy can you fart around. And hey, even Minecraft has some quest mode now, does it?

content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								tl;dr version, 8.5/10, still has a ways to go but as it is one of the most intense and realistic zombie survival games in a genre cluttered by easy fixes.There was no happy ending. This is how you died.I've been keeping up with Zomboid for longer than I'd like to think about. When it was first announced and gathering attention, the gaming world was abuzz with a zombie survival game the likes of which we had never really seen done well. The initial game they pumped out was fun and the promises of the game to come sounded like a dream come true for hardcore gamers.But as time went on, I lost interest due to slow updates. The game kept progressing, and every year or so I'd check up on it. I was generally impressed, but eventually just felt like there were enough zombie survival games emerging like Dayz that Project Zomboid had lost its chance. Finally, I decided to check its progress out one last time.And I was finally hooked.The experience it delivers is one that no other games to date have really offered. This is a true zombie survival horror game. It does not about action. It is not forgiving. You are thrust in the middle of a zombie apocalpyse with nothing but the clothes on your back and must survive any way you can for as long as you can. There is no happy ending here. The game only gets harder, and you will eventually die.You create your character picking a profession and using a beneficial/detrimental perk point system, meaning if you want your character to be strong you will have to give something up, such as asmtha or illiteracy. There are tough choices to be made, and many skills that are very useful. There are skills for cooking, gardening, foraging, and of course combat, and you are unlikely to get many of them very high unless you survive a long time. You will have to specialize your character.If you leave your oven on, it will burn your house to the ground. But maybe that's a good thing as you lured a horde of zombies to a house far from your safehouse and incinerated them all inside. The simple act of climbing through a broken window can give you an infection leading to death if you are not slow and careful. Running is taboo. Fighting every zombie is a chance of being bit and dead.The music is good ambient music that will set the mood, from a quiet slow terror to a banging intense beat if you are running from a herd. The sounds are functional and also quite terrifying. The graphics look nice while being low enough to be able to handle hundreds of zombies on screen and hundreds more off screen lumbering around. One thing that is not as functional is the animations, most of which are decent but I feel the game could use more of them to make things more clear in a game where there is no room for error.The game gives you a great amount of customization for your gaming experience, and you can start on a good beginner difficulty to learn how to survive in a safer enviroment or pump up the zombies from Dawn of the Dead to 28 Days Later fast and die quicker. Multiplayer is offered, but at the time of this writing has a long way to go to being something amazing. The potential is there and there are some great encounters to be had with some friends but public servers seem to still be off.This game is slow to move, but the developers are good about paying attention to the community and I have faith that if/when they finally deliver this game to it's full form, it will be the definitive zombie survival experience.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is amazing. When I first saw it on ImmortalHD's channel I thought it was a semi decent game that would be fun to play. Little did I know it would evolve into what it is now. This game has come along way with the addition of an advanced medical system and the (hopefully soon to be) addition of NPCs.Pros:- Interesting. Can keep you immersed if played properly for days- One of the MOST realistic survival simulators out there. (Might not be like DayZ, but in terms of survival it is)Cons:- Little boring on single player if you are new (I prefer multiplayer experiences)Little Multiplayer Story:Me and my friend were playing in a server. We decided to head to the hunting lodge up in West Point (That's where we thought the others in the game would be at) and found it to be empty of other players. We searched through the building to find a shotgun and a few shells. I was told to keep watch since I had no weapons and out of the corner of my eye I saw two men outside fighting off zombies. I screamed to my friend "THEY'RE OUTSIDE!! HURRY! I SEE THEM! THERE ARE PEOPLE OUT THERE!!" He came to the door only to bust out screaming shooting blindly at them. One was gunned down in the process and the other took a severe wound to his chest. I picked up his weapon and we followed him into the woods. We assume he bled out... but we will never know to this day.10/10 would search again

content:

Early Access Review
 Project Zomboid  Genre: Horror, Survival, RPG, Action, (Dying Simulator) Out of 10 what score would you give it?  I would give it  10/10  due to being a unique and different style of the overused zombie survival genre. Brief description of the gameplay: Project Zomboid is an isometric 2.5-D (A 2D image that simulates depth much like 3D) zombie survival game that is very much different from all of the other...generic zombie games, including a realistic medical system in which you MUST keep an eye on your wounds else you might not wake up the next morning! What was good about this game? Everything! I mean from the configurable settings to the weather and the amount of things you can do in the game, looking after yourself is vital to your survival from depression and boredom to stress & temperature, every aspect of the human condition is counted as a survival mechanism and for you to truly survive & thrive in this environment you must manage all of this effectively, failure to do so results in death, and not just "you die, and then respawn" once you die in this game the whole world is gone, you could call it permadeath, all of your hard work gone, just because you decided to investigate that abandoned police station. (Police stations are dangerous; I did this once, and died almost instantly).But that's not all, you have to scavenge for vital supplies such as food, water even rope & weapons, because after a while has passed (6 in-game months by default) water and electricity will be cut off to the town and you are left to fend for yourself. However you can build defences to not only hold off the advancing zombie hordes but to provide sustenance, shelter, warmth & storage.Food spoils and water becomes tainted, so what do you do? You build makeshift water catchers to provide clean & safe water, find seeds and plant crops in a safe place...look after them and maybe one day, they will flourish into clean, edible food!And to top it all off, updates, and the community, updates on game come out every Monday (They are called the mondoid) usually these don't include any game updates (they're usually once a month) but instead just what they have been working on for the past week, and they are usually interesting! What was bad about the game? I can't really think of much that is wrong with this game, other than that there are no NPC's (Non-player characters) and there are also no cars, but it has been confirmed that these things are going to be integrated into the game in the coming months.

Early Access Review
								For now, i want to say i really like this game. But there is only one thing that bothers me, to have REAL fun. You need to play multiplayer with friends, i mean. If you play singleplayer, it CAN get boring fast. If you play multiplayer... then it would be better. Still, if you want to play multiplayer, then you need to make your friends also play it. If you play on a random server, you will see COMPLETELY empty houses and even if there is 8 or 11 players on the server, you will not find them.One of the first time i played, i died of infection (zombie-infection) and it was really fun but after that, i wanted to try multiplayer... and for now i think there MAYBE should be an OFFICIAL server from the creators. If there was an official one, people would just join on it instead of trying to find a server or create a server.I really like this game and i hope they upgrade multiplayer a bit so it can be more fun.+ Simple GUI, no problem understanding it.+ The graphics are simple but they give a big effect, maybe because of the colors that blend into the apocalypse.+ Local multiplayer, online multiplayer, singleplayer and even multiplayer between different platforms.+ Many things your character can feel, panic, sad, sick, pain... everything.+ Many different skills you can give your character, but you need to balance it so you don't just take all positive things and so on. (I am right?)+ There is an tutorial! Welcome those who don't know how to play this!+ "Not so high system requirements."+ Support for controllers.+ Can be bought on Steam! Yay!- Early access, much things to add and bugs.- (I think) There is not so many options in customizing the look of your character.- I would like them to "upgrade" the graphics, to make them more detailed or (HD).- No campaign. (For now)- No plans for making it a console game. (The game would need to be re-written(Or something))[SPOILER ALERT]+ No way to survive(?) Already at the start when entering a world, the creators gave us a really good intro. *fade in* These are the end-times... *fade out**fade in* There was no hope for survival... *fade out**fade in* This is how you died... *fade out*"Click to skip intro"You think i gonna die? NO WAY! *Zombie bites me and i die some days after...*No sh*t, this game is reeeaaally hard. BUT I LOVE IT! :DDDDD[SPOILER END]

content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is amazing. When I first saw it on ImmortalHD's channel I thought it was a semi decent game that would be fun to play. Little did I know it would evolve into what it is now. This game has come along way with the addition of an advanced medical system and the (hopefully soon to be) addition of NPCs.Pros:- Interesting. Can keep you immersed if played properly for days- One of the MOST realistic survival simulators out there. (Might not be like DayZ, but in terms of survival it is)Cons:- Little boring on single player if you are new (I prefer multiplayer experiences)Little Multiplayer Story:Me and my friend were playing in a server. We decided to head to the hunting lodge up in West Point (That's where we thought the others in the game would be at) and found it to be empty of other players. We searched through the building to find a shotgun and a few shells. I was told to keep watch since I had no weapons and out of the corner of my eye I saw two men outside fighting off zombies. I screamed to my friend "THEY'RE OUTSIDE!! HURRY! I SEE THEM! THERE ARE PEOPLE OUT THERE!!" He came to the door only to bust out screaming shooting blindly at them. One was gunned down in the process and the other took a severe wound to his chest. I picked up his weapon and we followed him into the woods. We assume he bled out... but we will never know to this day.10/10 would search again

Early Access Review
								One of the most gruelling and unforgiving games ever made. This is for players who enjoy difficult games with a very singular focus. Be aware that this is not a "Zombie Shooter" but a survival sim set during a zombie event. Though unfinished the developers are hard-working, conscientious, and very responsive to the community. The game community itself is wonderful and supportive. Very active modding scene. Best of both worlds - great devs, great players. The game itself seems "retro" and limited at first but there is astonishing depth to it. I've put over 500 hours into this game and I'm only now grasping what it has to offer.Don't be fooled by gameplay videos - the default game map is huuuuuuuuuuuuge.10 / 10, excellent game.

content:
Posted: January 15
Early Access Review
								I've noticed recently that all the top review here are negative and I find it a bit strange, especially since the people giving those reviews are complaining about it getting repetitive and not enough being added recently. While I can understand frustrations over slow updates from the devs, but the game still has a lot of content and a huge amount of detail and complexity that you won't find in most games, especially zombie survivals or just survival games in general and more than that, the game is only 14 euro. Thats a really low price for a game that will provide u with hours of content. I notice that all these people writing negative reviews, in particular those who complain about the gaming being repetitive, all have 50+ hours in the game. That's a lot of hours for a 14 euro game that you claim not to recommend. I started playing project zomboid one day after my internet broke down and pz was one of the few games I could play offline. During that time I put around 10 hours into the game and loved. I died a lot, but I loved it because as I died I learned something new and I died from a variety of different problems, not just being killed by a zombie. Since then I've put another 10 hours into the game and another 5 playing split screen with a friend on his PC. I've had a lot of fun with this game as it is and even though updates are infrequent, the game still has hours and hours of content for a very small price. And considering that the people giving this a negative review have 50-100 hours in the game, I think they really enjoyed it too.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a well thought out zombie survival game that has plenty of developer support and modding/community support as well.  That's a combination to a sustainable and successful game which is what Project Zomboid is achieving.  For me I found the game refreshing because this game already has what many other zombie survival games strive to become.  There's a great crafting system, base building, various levels of difficulties, single player, co-op, or play as multiplayer.  One thing I particularly enjoyed is that the game doesn't hide the fact that you will die at some point(as the game becomes increasingly more difficult as times carries on and resources start to reduce(such and utilities being turned off permanently).  So every time you go out to scavange when you have survived for a while is a legitimate risk of the effort you have put in.Some issues with the game is the game is extremely harsh to new players, although this is getting better from the developers via tutorials.  I also suggest reading up on guides and the forum(something I didn't do initially, I jumped right in and turned into zombie food).  Some mechanics feel clunky, especially if you're used to playing with a controller, it feels more favorable towards mouse and keyboard, so be prepared for some adapting.With that all said I would highly recommend getting this game if you're a zombie fan, survival fan, or both.  You will find it rewarding and challenging at the same time.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								Project Zomboid is one of the best zombie games of all time although it is still in development. Some people might rant about the long time this game has been on Early Access and that some promised features are still yet to come. But they seem not to see the advantage in this longer development period. The devs really care about this game and every detail is made with love. I spent more than 1.000 hours in PZ and with every little update there is something new to explore. Bugs are rare and I never encountered any game breaking bug in a stable Build. There are frequent updates and if a bug is reported it usually gets fixed within days. But one of the best things in PZ is that the devs are in close contact with their community and a lots of suggestions made by the players have found their way into PZ. Moreover, there are plenty of options to customize your game and PZ can be easily modded and has a great modding community.I fully recommend this game if you are looking for a Romero-like zombie experience and if you are not too impatient in terms of ETAs.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								In the games current state, I'd have to say it's a do not buy from me.It's got a solid backbone to it, with skills, multiple weapons, character progression, and other things that a survival game should have, as well as a huge map, with mod support that adds more, but unfortunately the devs don't know which way they want to go with it.At one point they mentioned NPC's being in the game, that's long since been abandoned with nothing said about it, and most recently they've been working on new animations... for the last half year +.  The last few dev blogs have mentioned nothing about them, instead they've added VoIP for servers (in the age of Discord/Steam/Curse/TS/Vent/etc), and a new map (modders have added 5+ fully fleshed maps in that time).As I said there are mods for the game, and, sadly, they actually get updated more often than the base game.  Hydrocraft is a big one, and comparing the changelogs, there's a lot more going on in the mod, then the game.  New items are being added fairly often, bugs being fixed, and skills being added, when the base game has only just released a new map area...Very disappointed with the game as of now, I'd wait until release to purchase.Edit as of 2nd April, 2017:  It's been almost a year since the animations started getting worked on, and for the last few weeks - at least - we haven't heard a single thing about them, but there's all this stuff about vehicles coming in.  Wonder what they'll move onto when they're halfway done with those this time...The devs have no idea how to follow through with an idea, I feel like this game will never leave early access.

content:

Early Access Review
								This game is great.  I have yet to really delve into the multiplayer aspect of it much, but just even going solo is a lot of fun, and the game continues to impress with each update.  You really feel alone and helpless in this game as you run around and try to loot all you possibly can while you cross your fingers and pray for the items/tools/weapons you need to sustain yourself for just one more day.  The aspect I really love in this game is how you can set how early on the infection has been in effect.  You can set it early on so there's still indoor plumbing for easy access to water and electricity, or much later on during the infection where electricity is shut off and you rely on generators or just roughing it, and water being had from stockpiling water bottles or collecting rainwater in barrels.

								It's an 'okay' game, but the waiting process for any major updates is a killer. At the moment, the game feels kind of empty with no npc's (I'm one of those weird people who doesn't have high speed internet to play multiplayer) and I don't anticipate seeing them till around 2030, at least with their current development speed anyways. Don't get me wrong, I do like this game! But with it's current build status, it can get quite boring just walking around and surviving. Alone. When they get the NPC's and all of their other planned features such as cars, new animations (have been waiting for them 'anyday now' for the past 5 months) and a bigger world to explore, then I might be able to enjoy it more. But as is, meh. I want to recommend it, but for the sake of other people who might get trapped in this endless waiting game, I can't.

content:
Posted: October 22, 2016
Early Access Review
 Project Zomboid  This is a game in the early access about survival in a city overrun by zombies. The game is not like other survival games on steam where we kill each other for a can of potatoes. It is based on cooperation and helping one another to survive. Combat in the game is poorly done in my opinion, especially with gun as we find it so you should avoid fighting with infected because every scratch can be fatal. This does not mean that our main enemy are the zombies, this includes the weather, running in cold weather in the rain might end up as a death without adequate medicines. The same is about a evacuation from the second floor in case of danger, lack of adequate preparation can end up with a broken leg. Going through the broken window without clearing it may end up bleeding and a piece of glass in our body. Leaving the oven on at the night will end up a big fire and burning of our hero. Death is inevitable, you can fight but in the end you will fall. Everything can kill you cold weather, rain, bleeding, contact with infected and other deadly things but the most common cause of our death is our stupidity :D. The game graphically is not bad and the camera is set in an isometric view that can zoom in and out at any time during the game. I really like sound design and that the zombies react to loud sound, shooting, alarms, breaking out windows and random sounds can attract a considerable amount of zombies. The game is well developed, a huge map with great potential, the two cities and the country side. The survival of a bunch of days can satisfy. This production has a steam workshop thanks to the work of other players we can modify our game adding new things like vehicles, animals that may be hunted, a new city or even a prison from The Walking Dead. It does not change the fact that the game has a lot of downsides. One of them is that there is no map and we need to use website to find each other. There is no storyline but there was one very very long time ago. No NPC on the map, I think it would be cool move because playing the game on singleplayer seems to be a little empty. And the biggest downside is that the creators rarely update their production. The game has many advantages but it also has many downsides in my opinion which does not change the fact that the game is well made and worth buying, it means that I have no regrets because I have a lot of fun while playing this game alone and with my friends.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								Edit: The devs have replied everybody! WHAT a surprise. 25 man years? ... Please tell me this is a joke ... The massive stupidity displayed in the comments only proves my point. It would be funny if it wasn't so sad and pathetic. Bye~Why am I giving it a negative review? Well, it's the same old story.I was at one time invited by the devs to offer constructive criticism of the game onto their forums. I did so, and the devs promptly threw a hissy fit and tried to start an argument with me. I was then promptly banned both from the forums and from commenting on their Steam page - over nothing. These people will label constructive reviews as "Abusive" for being negative even if the review praises the game and offers constructive criticism. They'll ban anyone for speaking their honest opinions about this game in a respective way.Seen in the light of the development time and quality of updates, this does not reflect well on them. This is the negative aspect of indie gaming. The least you can expect from a gaming company is to be mature and respectful. Not so with many indie devs, including this team. (There's probably a quite a few people who work on this game and have no relation to such poor and unprofessional behavior.)They need a PR person.Here were my suggestions.- Special zombies and more challengesChallenges are actually really fun, but it seems like there no update on them and there's hardly any mods that add to them. (More on mods later.) Special and more challenging zombies will go a long way to make the game more enganging. A story will too, which is another issue about the game.The apocalypse happened, but there is no signs of people anywhere. It's just an empty map... The Drayton mod has much in the way of an envriomental story. (I highy reccomend that mod.)  In the Drayton map, there's blood and signs of death. Dead bodies left behind, some of people who decided to off themselves. There's spray paintings on the wall bemoaning the military and a cure. There's signs of struggle, of life, of a story... that map doesn't feel as empty even when you're the only one.Bad behaviored devs aside who don't know how to act maturely or take criticism, this game is very complex and well done. There's an intricate crafting system. The farming system is really well-done. The enviroments are huge and intriquate and fun to explore. The zombies have very interesting behavior and it really feels like you're trying to survive the apocalypse.But then we get back to the fact that the world is so empty.Here's how a typical playthrough will go.-Spend 30 mins creating a character-Get a weapon from the kitchen-Loot houses for supplies (This is the fun part)-Skip town because now the zombies are swarming you like there's no tommorrow-Head for a farm somewhere where there's a well (infitnite water)-Farm, farm, farm-Now you have infinite water and food. What now?Eventually you get bored and just kill yourself somehow, put the game down and then picked it up again a few months later. This game is best enjoyed in short bursts.There is really no longterm goal. The most fun I have is roleplaying different scenarios and acting how I really would if this happened in real life. It's funner to set yourself up for failure by boarding yourself up in your apartment and stay in the city or mall.Once you "learn" the game and the zombies aren't much of a challenge anymore, there's another problem that I mentioned before. Once you start exploring, the whole game feels so empty. There's no cars anywhere. Just empty roads. No signs of a civilization past. Just empty houses. Empty streets. Empty diners. Does that sound depressing? Well, it is. (In addition, the devs said that they'll be adding cars in the game FOREVER, and a modder already made a mod that adds working cars and abandoned cars in the game for free, on their own spare time.... go figure.)Zombie survival games are a dime a dozen now, and this game has been in development for more than half a decade. Think about that. What updates we get aren't anything to sing home about. The enviromental degration system and immersive sounds we're both made by a (great) modder. That's the only two updates that really added value to the game... in the meantime, they updated backpacks and now the TV's will spout nonsense repeatedly, the same 15 lines a million times over.People have devoted a large part of their life to this game, waiting for them to complete it and still there is no hint of the Big One. Npcs. A feature that will complete the game, and made it significantly more fun in addition with a long term goal of some story.I owe you a warning. The vision the devs have for this game probably isn't what you had in mind. As I said, I had some interaction with them before. They went of some pretentious rant about how 'humans are the REAL monsters' and explaining the artistic merit of Dawn of the Dead. Their vision for this game is more along the lines of The Walking Dead than a true zombie survival HORROR game.I'm sorry to Walking Dead fans. I sort of liked the show too, but WE GET IT. HUMANS ARE THE REAL MONSTERS. We get it everyone! Humans are bad. Violence is bad. Our basest of nature is bad. We are a bad and violent people.The reason why the Walking Dead is so hated is because of all of the dumb melodrama, and how the zombies stop being scary and become just background noise to whatever relationship problems some whiny brat has. (Who explicity has salon styled hair and high-end make up...) I said this before and I'll say it again. In the zombie world, zombies are the main character. We want to see horrors. We want to be scared. The ultimate nature of humanity isn't scary. It isn't horrifying. Sorry. Once zombies stop being the main character, then it stops being scary and we wake up from the nightmare.So I'm looking forward to the NPCs, but I'm not interested in the direction they are taking this. Fair warning. Dying Light is a good example of what I mean. The original story sucked and detracted from the quality of the game. However, The Following; the story was quite good and added a lot of depth to the game and zombie lore. The difference is that in the latter, the monsters were the main character in the plot. This is how horror succeeds where other genre's fail.But, by the time they finish NPCs the lifespan of this game will be long over. No Man's Sky is coming out soon. It's indie. The devs are actually friendly. It's complex and awesome, and suprise, surprise! It's actually finished within 10 years. Why waste time with drama and an empty, unfinished world when I can just play another game? Please tell me.This game has value, but be aware - before buying, it's just ANOTHER zombie survival game that's in EA that will probably never be finished within our lifespans.Oh, and to add insult to injury... they focused on multiplayer for $$$ instead of the NPCs.One last note: None of the mods for this game are that exciting. Wow, I get purple hair and now I can eat bugs. There's nothing really big in the mods section. The most popular mods are female nude mods and a Deadpool skin... enough said. Nothing to add challenge. No big overhaul, unlike the wild and creative mods you can get with games like Civilization. There is this one modder who said that they wanted to make a mod that turned this game into The Mist. Where did you go? Because that is a great idea. How about a mod that turns this game into The Thing?Here's an idea - wouldn't it be great if we could start playing while the infection is JUST beginning rather than AFTER the apocalypse already has started?Imagine it. You wake up, living your normal day like in real life. Then someone gets infected. It's slow at first, until people (NPCs) panic. More and more succumb to the infection. You are living the begining the the World War Z diaries. That would be great.This isn't that, but if only it were... it would be really good.

number of helpful: 18 of 34 people (53%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								In short: If you like watching progress bars this may be for you.  There seem to be a bunch of folks who really enjoy this game a lot, but it wasn't for me.I knew going in that this is an extremely detailed zombie survival game with a huge range of possibilities.  I'm OK with that, and I generally appreciate games that make some nod toward realistic world building (zombies notwithstanding, of course.)  My issue with this game is that it's just not fun.  I only played for an hour or so before I surrendered to the fact that it is just boring, plain and simple.  (I was playing offline, so steam doesn't track time properly; I actually had to play the silly thing again for online just so it would let me post a review.)The biggest issues I have are with the times required to do anything.  I actually like that it takes 5-10 seconds to fill a water bottle or a few seconds to dig some bit of electronics out of a cabinet.  What I don't care for is things like a baseball bat that takes 10 seconds to pick up, 20 more seconds to store in a backpack, 20 seconds to remove from the backpack, and finally 10 seconds to store in a cupboard when you get home.  If you find a nice collection of goods or equipment to bring home, you're going to spend a huge amount of time just waiting for progress bars to progress while you move items around in your inventory.  There needs to be a middle ground between the time required to deal with inventory tasks (looting, moving things around, etc) being meaningful and being wasted.  As it is, I felt like the game was more about watching progress bars than it was about zombies or survival.The book system is another offender in this way.  I was unable to actually read an entire book (Basic Cooking, mind you, not Rocket Surgery Level XVIII) because I'm not willing to wait 10 real minutes for a progress bar to complete in a video game.  220 pages at 2-3 seconds per page is a long time to wait while doing nothing fun.  Not surprisingly but higher skill level volumes have more pages still, so yay?  At first I was even more unhappy since the progress bar completely restarts whenever you move or do any action at all.  It appears that you completely restart the book but it does record partial progress (there's a small tooltip that shows how many pages you've read.)  I will say that recipes (plans for an electronic timer, let's say) are learned much more quickly (fewer pages, presumably) so that this isn't a problem for them.Just moving around and fighting are clunky as well.  Whack a zombie in the head with a baseball bat (you've got to be holding the RMB while you click the LMB, because reasons!) and it falls over.  If it doesn't fall in just the right direction (maybe within 15¬∞ off of your current view direction) or if it stumbles back a step before falling then your followup smacks are going to miss.  Gotta take a half step closer and adjust your angle slightly.  Whoops, you stepped on it instead, now you're swinging at the dirt past its head.  Perhaps ranged combat it less frustrating, but I never got there.If the exploration aspect of that game were lacking while the rest of the game (survival, crafting, etc) compensated for it, that could work, but as it stands, neither part of the game is worth it.  It's a game that is essentially sorting through inventories and watching progress bars broken up by a mildly frustrating game of exploration and zombie fighting.  I guess you die eventually, but I couldn't be bothered to get that far before quitting.
